title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Hate to say it but transfers and wages still have huge problems and you'll still see totally unbelievable deals being made. Ruins the experience completely and has been a problem for years so I guess SI simply can't make it work properly despite demanding endless examples in the bugs forum.

Examples (just a few but happens all the time, player is only involved in one of these so player is mostly observing).

Season 2
Bidding war for Jadon Sancho from Dortmund begins. Chelsea, Man Utd and Man City all table bids.
Signs for Chelsea for pretty cheap £52mil, despite a clear fricking bidding war.
Chelsea Squad status - Star Player - Wages a paltry 135kpw. No major clauses in the contract to make up difference.

Seriously, his agent must be on the Chelsea board.  
Kante Important player - 300kpw
Zouma Squad player - 205kpw
Rudiger Regular player - 200kpw
Kovacic Regular player - 150kpw
Ziyech Important player - 150kpw
Loftus-Cheek Squad player - £150kpw
Pulisic Regular player - £150kpw
Sancho -Star player - £135kpw (ridiculous)

"Yes your one of the best and most in demand young english attackers in the world so we'd like you to sign for us as a star player for less than half the wages of our important players and even less than a number of our regular players despite your huge reputation and the massive competition for your sig okay....Great, just sign here you fool."

-------
Season 3
Bidding war for L.Martinez from Inter begins. Chelsea, Bayern, Real, Barca, Man Utd, Man City all table bids.
Signs for Barca for £81mil. Squad status - Star Player - Wages a paltry 160kpw. No major clauses in the contract to make up the difference.

Seriously, his agent must be on the Barca board.  
Messi - Star player- 850kpw
Griezmann - Important player - 550kpw
Suarez - Important player - 350kpw
Alba - Regular player - 160kpw
Martinez - Star player- 160kpw (ridiculous)

"Yes your one of the best and most in demand strikers in the world so we'd like you to sign for us as a star player for less than half the wages of our other star players and the same as our left back despite the massive competition for your sig, okay....Great, just sign here you fool."

-------
Season 3
Bidding war for Leon Goretzka from Bayern begins. Chelsea, Real, Barca, Man Utd, Man City all table bids.

Signs for Real for paltry £61mil, less than his value despite squad status at Bayern being Star player and a clear fricking bidding war.

Real Squad status - Star Player - Wages a paltry 155kpw. No major clauses in the contract to make up difference.

Seriously, his agent must be on the Real board.  
Hazard star player - 550kpw
Kroos important player - 325kpw
Ramos important player - 225kpw,
Casemiro regular player - 160kpw
Carvajal regular player - 160kpw
Goretzka Star player - 155kpw (ridiculous)

"Yes your one of the best and most in demand midfielders in the world so we'd like you to sign for us as a star player for less than half the wages of our other star players and even less than some of our regular players despite the massive competition for your sig okay....Great, just sign here you fool."

-----
Season 3
Example transfer where player is involved and again it's with Chelsea.
Ruben Dias to Chelsea.
Player managing liverpool - Current European and Premier league champions.
Player Manager rep 4.5/5 stars
club rep 5/5 stars
last position - 1st - Champions league winners, EFL cup winners

AI Chelsea
Manager F.Lampard rep 2.5/5 stars
Club rep 4.5/5 stars
last postion - 6th - Qualified for Europa league. No trophies.

Liverpool transfer bid of 58mil accepted but his agent with no relationship to player or Chelsea refuses to even negotiate - reason - 'interest from Chelsea'

I'm like.... huh? Chelsea came 6th last year, won nothing, are playing Europa league and haven't even made a bid.
Forced to move on as will not even negotiate.
2 weeks later signs for Chelsea for 51mil and paltry 125kpw.

Seriously, his agent must be on the Chelsea board.  
Kante Important player - 300kpw
Zouma Squad player - 205kpw
Rudiger Regular player - 200kpw
Kovacic Regular player - 150kpw
Ziyech Important player - 150kpw
Loftus-Cheek Squad player - £150kpw
Pulisic - Regular player - £150kpw
Sancho -Star player - £135kpw (ridiculous)
Dias - Star player - £125kpw (ridiculous)

"We'll we managed to convince Sancho to sign for relative peanuts, perhaps you'd be equally as gullible yes? ....Great, just sign here you fool."

I'll accept some anomalies in the transfer system but when the biggest transfers in the game are so often this absurd then something is very wrong with it. This is a recurring problem year on year but SI thinks it's more important to have different hairstyles for your Avatar. I'll skip FM21 and probably FM22 as well.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
As a person who used to mainly play FIFA for the career mode unaware of Football Managers existence until 2017. 

I am astounded at how incredible this game is and I am disappointed in myself I didn't switch to this years ago. The detail put in to this game is incredible. If you're a true football fan to put it quite lightly, you will adore this game. At first I had a look at the menu I was handed and I'll be honest, I was confused. Never been more confused in my life. Gradually as I went on I learned more and more things and even now I'm still learning. I've only played so many hours (due to my low attention span I really can't just play the same game for hours and hours on end).

I can understand why when the matches actually take place the graphics aren't too great but it seems we've become lost where graphics are actually better than the rest of the game. I'd take Football Manager having the fantastic opportunities and detail given to me opposed to nice graphics for a 10 minute interval where I don't even have control directly over my players. It simply doesn't bother me and it shouldn't bother you. A million percent there could be improvement in graphics but it really shouldn't matter.

Personally, I bought this on sale for around £20 and if I'm being honest I feel like that was the right price for me to pay for this game. I'd advise to buy it on sale especially now considering FM21 is coming out soon which I will be honest I probably won't buy until it goes on sale. That's just me though, trying to save some money and feeling when the time is right.

If you're a massive football fan who loves and is intrigued with the game additionally love the tactical and managerial side, this game is for you. Don't think it's easy and you'll understand everything straight away otherwise you will not have a fun time!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've been playing FM20 for now a much longer time since COVID-19 and to be honest this game gets annoying fast. The AI is basically idiots and plays like a new comer. The game isn't that exciting when you have to go against a PL or Real or Barca rosters. One of my saves City has all there key players and also add Dybala, Joao Felix, Federico Chiesa, Neves, Declan Rice, Bentancur, Esposito for those who don't know this guy is OP in saves. and Mohamed Ihattaern. And many more top tier players the problem with this? Is its unrealistic the AI commonly does this and stack up with all there top players. And If your a smaller club they can raid your club for key players by tossing there weight around. and their whole roster is filled with overpaid players that no way they can get away with if the AI operates with FFP. But teams that splurge like this City are common United raided be for Dembele spent 109 million on him doesn't start him and he plays no games for them. Transfer list him a year later for 70 million? why did they spend that 100+ million with no attention of using him it makes no sense. this has happen multiple times and in every save I have done with small clubs. Keep this in mind City built that roster 3 years in its insane how stacked teams get. Another problem are AI clubs not selling players which can get dumb. I offered 20 mill for Kepa "That's his price in the game"  and Chelsea was refusing why you ask? IDK because they had Oblak starting so why would Chelsea hold on to a 10 mill a year back up GK. Is something you must ask the Devs themselves. Another issue I have ran into is injuries it seems only my team gets hit with them as hard. And when I say hard its like a punch from Wilder hard. Most of the players on your roster comes down with it. Which makes it so much harder to win crap cause not only are you factoring in your key players who play awful in game but also injuries. Every season I have played in this game at least 2 of my players go down with a 2 month + injury. Now to gameplay its not really all that much from what I feel. Many goals gain seem like stupidity and wouldn't happen in a real game. In a huge cup game my experienced players fold like a omelette. classic game sheets you will have in this game is 20 shots 11 on target AI stats 4 shots 1 on target. And this would resolute in a loss for you. I understand this happens in real life but clear dominance in game? And you are more likely tying or losing gets annoying. The game scripting ruins it hugely anyone who telling you they enjoyed this and its perfect is lying or a Bot. This game is riddle with glitches if you want actual real review go to the dicussion and the Discord the game sheets are memes now because its that bad. You can have a from 3 of Mbappe Ronaldo and Messi and they will all be pocketed by a MLS back line if the game in the mood for it. This game was made by a PL fan because they always win everything in my saves. All the saves are the same things same players are sold in all of them and same moves. and if you want to try and "build young" after 2 years they're all 100 million for 1 17 year old that hasnt played. But if you have a good young talent your getting offered 10 million. 
explain this game better if you new dont pick this up unless your willing to watch youtube videos or become tester. Cause the game doesnt teach you shit and you will be lost and trash if you depend on the game.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I had not really played any FM since 2016, as the games seems to lose their way. But FM20 really has addressed many of the biggest issues from previous versions. Proabably my favourite improvement is the game engine, where balls curve now and goals (esp FKs) are so much more realistic, as are crosses. No more ridiculous early yellow cards, players can actually play two games in 7 days without being completely tired out. In my first season didn't come across any crazy scheduling issues, although I was knocked out both cups early and was not in Europe...so let's see. It's great the way you can easily delegate tasks to staff and management, depending on how busy you are with other things. So far it is the best of the modern FM games and I highly recommend it.

MAJOR EDIT: Wow, now I've seen the posts from other players and realise this game is essentially broken. I'm into my 5th season with Everton, my vision was to be "best of the rest" and my goal was to qualify for champions league. I'm sitting in 4th with a few games to go, by far my best season....and I'm being told I failed my goals....by squad and owner. Owner BTW who is considering selling the club EVERY transfer window so I have a transfer embargo during critical times and miss out on sales or have selling deals messed up. PS I am in the semi final of Europa League when my goal was QF, not taken into account. Instead of being praised for a brilliant job (that the press is telling me I am having) instead am getting told off and having to beg to keep my job. What a load of **** sort if out. AND this stupid game is free now, what a waste of money. Never buying another version of this game.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: These recent iterations of the game we all love have felt somewhat soul-less, cluttered, and somewhat contrived. One of the striking disappointments is the SAME media questions being recycled for the 5th year running, which makes the whole thing feel monotonous. Symbolic, really, of how the franchise has lost its beating heart. The game is no longer fun anymore with so much crammed onto the screen (for stats sake) the eyes are overwhelmed by text and numbers on skins that are cheap and garish. The 3d match engine gets worse with each iteration, and 2020's effort resembles a 6th formers animation project, with players gliding surreally gliding around the pitch loosely coinciding with ball movement. Goal replays are dampened as the ball crashes into the net and the spectators remain seated, and then... oh, they're up and celebrating a little while after. The training screen is so busy now, it just makes you want to ignore this aspect of the game because its simply to onerous to manage or understand how on earth any of it will impact upon your team. The Player Search list is now cumbersome with each player listing now 2-3 rows in width which prolongs the process of browsing for players. Since 2017, the joy has simply been sucked out of these games by a developer who seems intent on ripping out everything that was good about the game and replacing it with ridiculously packed screens of mostly inconsequential data. Sega/SI would be better off building a baseline game based on some of the better versions, and simply keep it updated. They'll still be quids in. The constant unnecessary tweaks to the game are killing it.

In this game I never play as a U.S. team as U.S. sports have tons of criminal records and tons of politics rather than entertainment. My wife is Brasilian so I play mostly Brasilian teams. I'll keep playing FM since I already paid, but, thanks to disgusting players and commissioners in sports I will no longer purchase any sports games that are based on real players or teams. Nothing that gives income to spoiled and disgustingly behaved overpaid sports. I have already marked FM2021 as Ignore in Steam and mark all sports based on real life as ignore now.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: I am not even a soccer fan but even not being a fan of the sport, there is no doubt in my mind that this is the greatest sports game ever created. The depth of it absolutely blows everything out of the water except maybe Out of The Park Baseball. Early on I hated that I couldn't instantly sim through matches but I have grown to love how invested I am in every game over a long season and the buying and selling of players is a fun and rewarding element that no other sports games can really match.If you like, sims buy it. If you like sports, buy it. If you like don't like either, buy it on sale anyway. Just know that its extremely addictive.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: I don't often play sports games. When I do though, they mainly consist of racing titles such as F1, or Assetto Corsa. And, in this case, Football Manager. I'm still relatively green, so to speak, to this series, starting with 2019 last year. As someone who does enjoy football, I felt as though I'd be doing myself a disservice [i]not[/i] trying out FM2019. I enjoyed it, of course. That's why I'm here writing a review for FM2020.[hr][/hr]I will be honest. I suck at this game. But. Honestly? That's part of the fun. A lot of FM's charm comes from the audacious (and scarily realistic) it can be at times. For instance, in 2025, Manchester United re-sign Cristiano Ronaldo for £200 million, or something ridiculous. And FM has gotten these kinds of things correct in previous titles. [hr][/hr]The amount of control you get is second to none. I mean. It has to be. [i]You're[/i] the manager. Other football titles such as FIFA and PES offer a more casual experience, but lack any sense of control with what you do. You control one player at a time and have to pray and hope the AI doesn't decide to alt+F4 itself. (In FIFA's case, it does that all the bloody time) Football Manager, on the other hand, is more complex than that. While you don't control any single player, you do control how the team behaves. Do they go for the attack, wanting to demolish their opposition? Do they sit back and defend for their lives to win a relegation 6-pointer or prevent their title rivals getting the upper hand on them?[hr][/hr]If you are inclined to, you can always start from the ground up as a new and upcoming football club. From the grass-roots of Sunday League, where players eat pie and chips with a pint of bitter to boot for breakfast; to the glory of lifting the Premier League (or Premier Division due to licensing rights; this can be changed with the free FM20 Editor add on) trophy. [hr][/hr]TL;DR - if you're a football fan and you've not played Football Manager, where have you been? If you want complete control over your team, this is the game for you. Trust me; you'll never go back to the overpriced roster updates FIFA and PES.

review: This game has so many bugs - player was sent off for two yellows, and then was not banned for the next match, even though I received a news item that he was. I can also live with inconsistent results and performances, but how many times does the AI need to score in the 90th minute when you are controlling the game  for this to be considered unrealistic (I appreciate tactical changes), but some of them just do not make sense, such as you have 70% possession, the opposition have 0 shots, and then  construct two moves completely not in keeping with either the match, the prescribed outlook of the manager, or the players involved - not to mention my players forget tactics that they have been using without issue in previous matches - it's like once the game gets to 90 minutes, teams are automatically managed by a robot Jurgen Klopp, despite how they've played for the previous 90 or previously during the season

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I always buy these games, right back since the old Champ Manager games. I bought them because I love football and because  I always felt the actions I took would have some effect on the game. Sadly not in this one. Your choice of tactics have absolutely no bearing on the outcome. Ask them to play a short passing game and they will boot it long, ask them to ease off tackling and you'll get 4 or 5 Yellow cards. ....and so many disallowed goals...and never ever a handball!!
To check it out properly I used the FM Editor, boosted 7 or 8 of my York players to Premiership level  ratings...absolutely zero effect. i still got the sack.
i'm digging FM 19 out and starting with that again.
Very disappointing.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I have been a hard-core fan of FM since FM 2015. The game just keeps going from strength to strength every year. And this year, it got even better! It also helps that this really feeds into my OCD and the management aspect of football is lacking in the other 2 major football games (FIFA and PES). I was playing the Demo for most part of the year (too expensive) before buying the full version recently (on sale). Short summary:

Pros:
Very deep and informative system
All inclusive in terms of various aspects of the sport
Refined Match Engine (compared to previous titles)
Scores of options to start your journey (I always start out unemployed)
Widest collection of clubs and countries and national teams
A huge community online to keep engagement

Cons
Lack of licenses (easily fixable with mods)
Sometimes different features of the games can be too difficult to understand
Almost too in-depth sometimes to have fun playing (I haven't experienced this but many people I know have)
The game can be brutally unforgiving at times

And that's my short review! I might edit in the future if I feel something should be added/removed. Have fun managing!

title: Football Manager 2020
review: This game is one of the best versions of FM I have played, and I played FM15, FM16, and FM18. I like many things about it but especially I like that it gives you a lot of control over players' training. What I do not like though is how difficult it is to score. My team creates so many clear-cut chances, and then goes on to miss like 95% of them! Even though I have really good strikers and inside forwards, and I keep training "chance conversion", my team still misses far too many chances for comfort. The AI though, it only needs 1 chance to score 1 goal. It is so frustrating. But overall, I would say the positives far outweigh the negatives, as far as FM20 is concerned. I recommend it.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: Some describe football as a way to escape the mundane practices and monotonous schedules that seem to plague us all. I agree with this, to an extent, as there is nothing more fruitful than being able to connect spiritually and emotionally with the team you support on the football pitch. However, while playing this game, the only thing I can connect with is my fist to the screen because this game is utter nonsense, it is the epitome of crap, it is the personification of a headache. Aight, so listen, hear me out. Why the heck do my players always become prime Mo Salah when they are in the box, they literally need 10 good chances to score 1 goal. Not only that, my players seem to become Raheem Sterling in the sense that not only do they only score tap ins, they also crapping miss tap ins. What the heck. Nah, we can't let us this fly. Not to mention that your team could have 30 shots but lose to a team that have 5 shots. Yeah, that does happen in football sometimes, I ain't disputing that, but this happens literally every 3 games in FM. They should change the abbreviation to "FML" at this point, cuz that's how it feels like when I'm playing this game. It's a great game with a lot of potential, but just like my 4 and a half Star Illian Mesiler, that potential was utterly destroyed by the shitness of the gameplay aspect in this game. CROCK! Utter crock! FIX YOUR GAME! :angry_face:

title: Football Manager 2020
review: If you love  football management games  I strongly suggest you buy this fantastic game - I bought it nearly a month ago and I can hardly leave my computer !!! -  - It only has one real fault in my opinion which I will come to in a moment - as for the pluses - where to start - if you support one of the big clubs and want to challenge for the trophies - away you go - if ,like me, you want to start at the bottom and work your way up - that is where the fun lies - there are 1000's of players in the search engine for you to buy or loan in building a team ,loads of tactical permutations - you have to deal with press (even in non-league), sort out contracts , keep your players happy  if they are not in the side ,suffering injuries and suspensions going through a long hard season, way too many things to mention here - the best bit about the game though (for me) is that you can literally invent your own club (choose your own name)  and customize your own players , so if you have been a fan in real life for many years you can re-invent your old favourites from many years ago with all their own strong points and weaknesses and resurrect them to bring success to your club - I'll end the review with the only real minus point - the match  itself shows selected action and skips certain points of the match so it can get a touch frustrating when you don't see what is happening at times - other than that - a huge thumbs up

review: I'm a huge fan of the FM franchise. But I've encountered a problem with the current release, FM20. I usually mix between either the full system on PC or the mobile version - usually preferring the mobile as I can play more freely. But I opted for the full version this time around, but it runs super slow on my pc. I guess it's my pc but when I deleted all unnecessary things on it to make it work and still only get 1star performance on the smallest database i just find it too slow and takes forever to get through any loading screens. If I had just went with the mobile version I would be happy.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've been playing different entries of football manager/championship manager since the late 90s and I've liked some and disliked others. Unfortunately, football manager 2020 will definitely go in the disliked category for me, which is really a shame because there are several things about the game that I did like. The interface is pretty,  lot of the club management features work well and new additions such as the club's vision and the development center are pretty cool and add to the overall experience. 

The major problem with football manager 2020 however, at least in my experience after having played this years' game for 50+ hours (plus about 20 hours with the demo), is that this year's version is incredibly frustrating and just not that much fun at all. I really wish I could go back in time and not pick up the demo or pay for the full game because overall I feel that I just wasted a great deal of my time, and a little bit of money, and have gotten very little enjoyment in return. In fact, most of my time playing this year's game has been mostly terribly stressful and frustrating. 

My only save in this year's game, which I started with the demo, was managing Juventus (called Zebre in this year's version since they didn't have the full naming rights for the team). After struggling to win the league in my first year (ended two points ahead of second placed team, AC Milan) I finally had a pretty decent second season winning the league comfortably after bringing in a bunch of new signings such as James Rodriguez, Cavani, David Neres and David Silva. My performance in Europe meanwhile was truly embarrassing, having been eliminated in the group stage in the first season and in the round of last 16 by Lyon in the second season (got killed in the away game 0-3), despite having a pretty great team. However, it was truly in my third season that things got ugly. After signing a number of great players, some young and promising (Fabio Silva, Antony) and others highly skilled and experienced (Aubameyang, Oblak) I started the season by beating Roma 3-1. This was the kind of result that I would have expected and I was happy to start the season with a victory. After that it was all downhill though, getting destroyed by Napoli (1-5 away) in the second game and accumulating a number of bad results after that no matter what I tried to do. This is when I decided enough was enough and uninstalled the game.

I understand that winning all the time would not be fun or realistic but it just felt that I was really not having all that much fun at all with this year's game and that overall the game just wasn't fair. The basic team and tactics that had allowed me to comfortably win the league in my second season all of sudden simply didn't work at all and after I started losing there was no stopping the bleeding essentially. Really, no matter what I did I could not get good results or have the team play well, especially away from home, and while I want the game to be realistic I just didn't feel that it was.

In FM 2018, the last FM I played before FM 2020, I had enjoyed a tremendously successful run with West Ham, having eventually built up the club to win the Premier League several times and even win the Champions League, and even though away matches had always proved difficult I never had the same degree of underperformance as in this year's game. I really feel that the game is either not fair or it is not telling the players what they should do to correct their mistakes and have their teams perform better. 

Overall, I would certainly say that I wish I hadn't played this year's game and I really, really hope I don't make the same mistake next year and buy this game, even at a discount. The game requires too much of a time investment in my opinion to ultimately deliver such a frustrating and unfair experience. My advice is stay away from this game or play at your own peril...

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I am reluctantly going to give this a thumbs down. Now, i'm reluctant because i do enjoy the game, as i'm pretty sure anyone who likes football and/or management games would do to some extent. The problem with it is the lack of realism in the matches and results, which has been an issue in previous versions but nowhere near to the same level as in this 2020 version.

I will give some examples of what i mean. There have been games where my team has completely outplayed the opposition, i have had over 30 shots on target, over 50 shots in total. The opposition has 2 shots, guess which team wins that game 2-0? That's right, not mine. Throughout these games their 2 star goalkeeper makes absolutely world class and, in many instances, physics breaking saves that would quite literally be impossible in real life. Meanwhile my 4.5 star at this point best in the game goalkeeper can't even catch a ball. The goals the opposing team scores are almost always shots that should be saved with ease. I have seen the opposition keeper save a shot that is hit from 2 yards, as hard as it can be and right in the corner yet somehow their keeper saves it. As i said, physics breaking and completely unrealistic.

Now this has been a problem that has come up in previous version of the game, but before it would happen in maybe 2 or 3 games a season, which i guess was supposed to represent that on very rare occasions you may get a game like that. In this 2020 version this seems to happen almost every other game. It completely spoils the realism and immersion of the game when you beat a title rival 5-1 then the next week lose 1-0 to the team which is bottom of the league even though you have 25 shots on target compared to their 1 shot. 

So, this is why i am reluctantly giving this years version a thumbs down. I enjoy it, you will probably enjoy it, but the complete lack of realism is very jarring and very frustrating. Especially so when they like to advertise themselves as being the most realistic manager sim out there. If i were you i would do yourself a favour and buy the 2018 version, update the player lists with mods. That's the best version of the game in the last 5 years.

Score:-

Fun: 1/10
Replayability: 0/10

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Based on reviews, I avoided FM 20 on full price and bought it on sale. I still wouldn't call it value for money. 

Fundamental problem is the match engine. Players dwelling on the ball, losing possession in their own half and conceding a goal. Players absolutely failing to score 1v1. There is also a massive lack of consistency to performances. EG - I have had 70+ percent possession and only registered 1 shot on target with Work Ball into the Box. 

As a test - I ran the same fixture approximately 10 times, using different formations, line-ups, tactics, so on. A team about 4 places and 6 points below me in the league, who we beat 3-0 previous fixture. Every single time we lost by at least one goal. 

Don't but it. You feel cheated and no sense of satisfaction.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I find it utterly disgusting to watch advertisements ingame after paying full price for it.

Board expectations are extremely unrealistic. You always need to do better than last year in order to please the board. Also the board always forces you to play certain playing style, which you can't negotiate even with godlike determination skill. Also the interface is disabled to change the level of importance to certain requirements.

Player training is fake, players have baked in attributes that you "unlock" via training, but you can NEVER train something that you think the player would actually benefit from.
Absolutely retarded training system.

Match instruction options are far few and uncreative and repetitive.

UI has so many glitches all over the place, for example setting up set piece takers is ultimately bogus.

You can opt to have your assistant manager to handle the ultimately boring and repetitive and goddamn stupid interview questions, but it will obliterate your media handling reputation, reducing your chances to get another job.

If your team fail to produce results, it is career ending, don't expect any job offers, regardless of your legendary manager skills, your reputation is irreversibly annihilated.

Old players skyrocket into being useless at a much faster rate than in reality. It is laughable how all football manager game predicted Christiano Ronaldo to deteriorate hungarian division 3 level. And guess what, yet he is still playing for Juventus, how come dudes? To make it even worse, in this game they will NEVER accept lower salary. Even if they play at the level of a 2nd world war veteran at the age of 110, they will ask more than in their prime years. Rendering all old players not just a big gamble, but an expensive money waste.

Game loading is disabled during a match. Making save scumming the most annoying experience in this game.

At least it's realistic that all the English leagues are full of useless overpriced crap! At least you don't need much brains to do well on the transfer market. Avoid English players like the plague and you will do just fine.

Btw transfer market expectations of the board is also ridiculous. When you want to meet league criteria, you need to buy players from your own nation. But they are limited. All the clubs are fighting for them, driving up their price. Especially the good ones. When you sign players that play international level, you will always hear the board whine about their price. Even though you kind of assembled the best team within your nation, they will crybaby about it. Ridiculous.

Then the transfer revenue percentage. Every now and then they will reduce your transfer revenue percentage, just because why not. Although it takes just about asking them to raise it back - to make it completely retarded.

Oh, god no, the coaches. There are so few that are actually good. Coach training is completely useless. You can't realistically max out your coaches.

Also improving your training facilities. Takes tens of years. You can bump it once every year. And you can only afford that if you won every match that is physically possible with your dudes - and it takes all your revenue. Tell Ronaldinho that it takes billions of dollars and tens of years to get a proper training facility together. They can't just kick the rubber in a courtyard, cos that way they will never have the "potential". So freakin dumb mechanic.

Sponsors are nearly non-existent. Even if you massively over-perform and somehow cheat yourself to win the Champions league with a lower division team. You will still only have the 100$ yearly backing of the local grocery store. Maybe you will get an extra 30$ offer from the local fake KFC clone.

If you manage to improve your team, you will end up having all the old shitty players whine about playing time - even if they regularly play in your B team against opponents that they used to fight against. No they complain, that they want to play against Liverpool with their one and a half star rating.

Youth. Omygod! You can have godlike coaches, if you have your youth facilities too low, you will always end up getting complete garbage players.

Additional training focus is just a joke. A player with a skill of 5 on penalties can't improve it. Just forget it. Even though if Ronaldo and Messi are mentoring him together. I guess a cripple in a wheelchair has better prospect to be a professional fotballer in reality than your youth players in this game.

Custom team actually doesn't fully give you the freedom. And you can't delete your custom players, so if you made a mistake and create the same player slightly modified, it will have a clone.
Also the original modified team's members will be available on a free transfer. For example if you sack the Barca, you will have all the top players available for free and suddenly Manchester United will buy all of them, good luck winning champions league with your custom team after that!

There is no easy to understand guide how you should set your team to succeed. Trial and error is completely useless cos of extreme RNG.

From all the above, the predetermined player skills are the most annoying as this mechanic completely takes out the long term strategy of football. Why would you adopt a certain training if the players have LOCKED-IN skills that never react to any kind of training, even with godlike coaches and godlike training equipment and quadruple training intensity, they will simply say: No effect.

So all it remains is a transfer market game. Buy the players with the skills already in place. Because you can't train them as you like.

Overall the game is extremely restrictive. Slow paced and annoying experience. Overpriced garbage, with terrible graphics and over-complex UI for the average user.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
FM2020 is another chapter in this series, and it remains in some ways fulfilling but mostly disappointing.

Fulfilling:
- Managing a football/soccer team, signing players, scouting, tweaking tactics
- Silly fun
- Playing in MLS
- Building from the bottom of a pyramid in England to the top
- Load/save (best feature of the game)

Lame:
- The game is harsh and illogical, yoyo-ing results even as you build a consistent deep team that wins, wins, wins. One minute your GK saves amazing goals - the next minute, he doesn't know what the ball is doing.
- Broken stat/attribute systems that don't really make any sense.
- Your tactics are probably fine - the game is dumb.
- The computer switches tactics far faster than a human player or manager ever could. This should be fixed.
- Win 20 games in a row? Doesn't matter - the next game your guys will forget how to pass out of the back, always head balls to opponents, and struggle.
- Win championships? Your players will still act shocked when you tell them they are capable of beating Manchester United in the Carabao Cup final, and then you go and do it, and then next time, they still act shocked when you suggest they are capable of winning it all. So dumb.
- Go unbeaten in a season and then play like they hardly know each other in a game against a tougher opponent. Seriously, fix this!

In other words, don't buy this game until it is cheap, cheap, cheap.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
If like me you haven't played since 2016 due to it being too "samey" then I would give this iteration a definite buy. 
So much has changed since then and for the better. The match engine is brilliant compared to 2016. It still needs work on the collision physics but overall i'd give it a solid 8 out of 10.

Tactics are deeper than ever but also easier to understand and master. After a few hours adapting to the new UI I feel connected to the action more than ever before.

It's a great game and i'm so happy to see how it has matured and am enjoying playing very much.

If you can get it on a deal its more than worth your investment. But if you haven't played for a few years then now would be the time to jump back in deal or not.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Been playing this game since Commodore (Amiga) version. Like many other loyal lovers of this game, i experienced so many exciting moments, so many disappointments, so many 'last minute' victories or tears. I still remember when i was having my press conference speech in the kitchen while preparing my coffee or my sleepless nights because of a title game in the next day. but i never thought one day i would mark this game as 'not recommended'.

For my humble opinion, this game was still ok until 2017 release, where i was not suffocated with too many, but really too many details, which kill the enjoyment of the game. if i really wanted to become a football manager in real life, i would do what is necessary for it. but wait: this is just a 'GAME'. This ,(at least) 'WAS' a game when there were 'acceptable amount' of details. This was a game when there were 'acceptable amount' of challenges,which were still pushing me to use my brain. 

It now turned out an algebraic calculus where i should take all the tiny hells into consideration. I am sure some people would now say: This is the realism. Really? Are you guys sure Football is something like this? Are you guys  seriously sure that any of the managers in real life calculate the effect of 'intuition' or 'determination of a backup left wing on the pitch? where is your passion guys? who cares about the match engine? Give me my 2D dots back instead but please do not kill my game with your millions of stupid details. This is not the FM i know and love.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
FM 20 is a fully immersive management game taking you from the depth of despair and frustration through the tedious day to day hum-drum of dealing with the press to the elation and joy of winning your first cup or league.  Building a winning team team is not just a matter of buying players supermarket style but needs thought about club finances, personal relationships with club players and proper fit into your system. and is he injury prone.
If you're not careful hours can disappear while you try to appease the board and the fans, selling promising youngsters to balance the books. In contrast it's a moment of joy when a U18 graduate pays back 5 years of training by scoring the winning goal at Wembley.
If you're prepared to give up your sun tan, your job, your girlfriend then this for you.
COYWs!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Honestly it's football manager and I like football manager; if you do as well you'll like this. The negative review is because there is little effort put into the series, FM has been little more than a roster update with minor tweaks. Just compare it to out of the park baseball which completely blows it out of the water. In comparison this looks like a budget title but it isn't. About the only things FM does better is scouting and the 3D looks better. It's getting a little boring that there's never any real additions.

Ootp has you start at any time with the rosters and rules of that time with the players emerging and rules been added as time goes on. Customise the rules. Create new leagues with new teams easily with an easy way to give them logos and jerseys. Adding custom jerseys and logos is much easier in general you could easily change them out every year if you wanted. Put players of every era in so for example want pele and zidane in 2020 go ahead. Feel you can have a much bigger impact on the match with tactics and choices though this is partly because baseball is easier to do that for than football. A match engine that makes sense and works. It runs considerably faster and better they also call their skip a skip instead of a holiday. Even something as minor as the facegen is better. What have we gotten in FM? Tweets and press interviews :).

I'd like them to add something major for once but have a feeling this review will probably be as relevant to FM 2025 and 2030 as this one :/.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Actually the worst FM of all the series I've played.

I have been playing FM since 2008. And I can honestly say that this one is the worst one I've played. I know the users have been saying this is a glorified roster patch for 50 bucks. I would say this version is not worth it even with the sale. 
Match engine is made horribly making me question (yet again) the development capability as much as their knowledge of football altogether. They clearly wanted to implement the line breaking with throughs, but they didn't have the capability to code the defender's to react so they made the 1 on 1 chances : scoring ratio ridiculously high to offset that. 
I think this may be the last FM series I would purchase because it's never been this clear that Sports Interactive actually doesn't care at all about the user feedback.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This is the worst iteration of football manager to date.

I've sunk hundreds of hours into this game in a vain attempt to enjoy it. The match engine is an utter disgrace and this game is going the same way as FIFA: yearly updates with minimum effort due to a lack of competition.

A company that goes out of its way to say that it is no longer providing updates for a game that doesn't work properly in March, a mere 4 months after release, does not deserve support. The next game probably won't release until November/December, meaning that there will be 10 months of absolutely no updates between releases. A shocking practice that isn't worth supporting.

Not buying next years FM until it's out of beta and I've seen enough evidence that they have improved the match engine.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: Into August now and 1v1 finishing is still broken. It doesn't matter who the player is, how high their finishing, composure or technique is, 9/10 times they will miss. Shots in 1v1 situations actually end up closer to the corner flag than the goal. Absolute shambles. Players also don't listen to tactics. No point telling your players to put in low crosses because you have small forwards because they never cross low. Most crosses are in the air regardless of instructions. Players can't tackle either. Constantly sliding about and giving away a foul or not coming away with the ball. My first and probably last FM game, for a while at least anyway.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've loved this game since it was Championship Manager, but unfortunately it's been going downhill for some time.  The match engine feels like it's been programmed by people who have never seen a game of football in their lives, the tactical options are full of annoying arbitrary details (sorry, your midfielder is a 'mezzala' not a 'carrilero' so they can't effectively do what you want them to do) that make it feel more like a series of traps you have to navigate rather than a way to help you get your players to do what you want.  Which they won't, by the way.  For the quintessential FM2020 experience, just ask your team to 'work the ball into the box' and watch them pass it sideways back and forth until the entire opposition team is behind the ball, and then either stand still shuddering on the spot like a pensioner having a stroke until they get dispossessed, or give up and smack the ball against the nearest defender.  If you try to play attacking football, you get beaten by long balls over and over.  Try to defend and watch 25 yard worldies repeatedly scream into the corner of your net.

Devs, if your thinking was that it was too easy to pick any team and conquer the world with them - yes, it was.  That was the point.  That was the fun.  Please lose the traps and bring back the fun.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I had the older game in 2013, and a lot of things are improved and game seems less random than it was in 2013 (although the engine still has issues in match making). There is a lot more new stuff and better graphics added to the system, and many more clubs to enjoy.

The biggest issue I have is there is bunch of LGBT flags almost on every stadium including Turkish and Russian clubs but also when you do other matches in non-registered teams like Middle East, makes 0 sense to have LGBT on Saudi Arabia, and it feels like Devs are promoting so much to spread political values on a football game. I have no issue seeing LGBT flag on Western clubs, but seeing these on Turkish or Russian teams or in Africa, Asia or Middle East makes 0 sense and a perfect example of 1st World Liberalism forcing values on 3rd World countries, and acting like they are inferior or barbarians.

Without the forced Western Liberal values on other countries it is a good game, but I hope Devs will either respect local cultures more or make more realistic scenarios when it comes to these politics. After all we had a World Cup on Russia and soon on Qatar and FIFA did not care much except the money part.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
A review from a player who had 500 hours in FM19 ( the real number is more than 1000hrs i believe) and someone who had played the series for 10 years since i was a kid.

If you are new players: It's a must play which improvements from FM19. But its not change much compare to the last, if you jump from FM15 or FM16, it will be a whole new experience. But from FM18 and 19, not so much.
Good:
- Youth Academy is a good add on. I think they should make it long time ago not until 2020.
- Staff is now very active and lively. Head of youth development is actively seek and buy youth prospect at a bargain price. The old version just splash lots of cash, pay overprice for a youth player.
- Match Engine: a little more realistic, speed, strength and balance actually show clearly in the match. You will see the clearly different between a fast and slow player, an outpace or a successful dribble is satisfying to watch, also there is fake turn where the attacker trick the defender by dribbling in the opposite direction. A strong and good player will still standing and not lose the ball even taken 2-3 successful tackle from opponent.
- I haven't seen any weird angle shot yet like many players report.
Cons:
- Match Engine: yep, still ME, I gonna break down each situation below.
In 2019 ME, when ST receive ball in the middle, he will dribble and usually lose the ball or try to pass to the wing and slowly run to the enemy third. Its usually not end up in a goal.
2020 ME, ST receive the ball with a beautiful touch and turn on Saiyan mod. Dribble through both the defenders and 1v1 with the goalkeeper.
And talk about the 1v1, what seperate it from real life is i never seen an attacker that lob the ball, dribble around the keeper  or nutmeg. Just a boring hopeful shot.
- Player's value: I have a feeling that the value of player is higher than previous years, some player with very normal stats, sure he have potential but no way that guy price is 30~40 mil. In FM19 my player would be very good and it take a top performance season to reach 20 30 mil.

100% recommend, great job SI.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This game (and the games before it) converted me into a football fan, and I had barely any appreciation of sports before that point.

Football Manager is, in gaming terms, like a grand strategy RPG. You have the grand strategy element of heaps and heaps of numbers going up and down and the initial confusion of understanding what any of them mean, as well as being able to play for 400 hours (like I have) and realise you understand absolutely nothing about the game, and still having that creeping feeling that you really don't know what you're doing.

The RPG element comes from your players. Each of your players has their own wants and needs, and you have to balance your match day squad as best as possible. It's not just a case of "who's best at what" (although sometimes it can be) - you might need to settle a disgruntled player, or give one of your younger players a chance to shine and get some experience in the first team.

It's hard to show what the appeal of the FM series is unless you really sink your teeth into it. I can honestly say I get ridiculously immersed in this game. You experience the highs and lows of your labour, cringing when your team has an awful defeat and cheering when they do well. Were you responsible? Was it just RNG? Who knows, but it's fun, isn't it? Trying to work out what's actually you and what is just smoke and mirrors is part of the fun.

What I'm trying to say is, even if you're not a fan of football and sport, if you have an interest in grand strategy or complex RPGs you may just appreciate the incredibly diverse and immersive game that has the potential to grab you here. For me, players like Alessandro Rossi, Hendrick Weydandt and Luismi are burned into my brain, and I've gotten a brand new appreciation for the complexity and nuance that the sport of football has. This IS the beautiful game, but not as you know it.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
GENRE>>>>>>>>>>>MANAGEMENT
Squad, staff and club management.

GAME-PLAY>>>>>>>>8
Good. For gamer's who love to analyse lists,stats and look at lots of info. Should be higher but has some annoying and frustrating elements in the match engine. Like forwards struggling with one-on-ones (!?!?!) and players taking impossible angled shots instead of making an obvious pass. You'll cheer and you'll curse so i guess the end result is good enough.

GRAPHICS>>>>>>>>3
Bad. So bad that a lot of ppl don't even use the 3-D match engine and still use the older 2-D mode or even the text only mode. Fifa 2000 has better graphics. The vanilla user interface and menu layout is not great and has only changed its colours the last 8 years. Most ppl play with user made UI's.

MUSIC&SOUND>>>>5
Average. No music. Sound effects are ok, they do the job. But little to no attempt to incorporate more stadium atmosphere or teams chants. 

POLISH>>>>4
Average. This series has a reputation of not making any major changes to the core experience. With every years game basically being a database update. Every edition needs a patch to sort numerous issues out from the launch version. You could for example play FB manager 2012 and not notice to much difference in overall experience. With the most notable changes since then being more depth surrounding injuries(sigh) and some minor interface changes and menus that show things that used to be hidden like team hierarchy, squad dynamics. Which since i can remember has been part of the game, players just lacked visual representation of those aspects.

REPLAY VALUE>>>>8.5
Good, almost great. Mainly a single player game but multiplayer is possible, as well as steam leader boards. If you are big football fan and really get into this game it could really suck you in and you could find yourself putting hundreds of hours into this. You could play with one team to the year 2100 if you manage not to get fired or you could jump around to different leagues or even manage international teams if you are bored of club football. For me the game gets really interesting when the original "real player" database is fazed out eventually and gets replaced by newly generated players and where scouting becomes one of the most fun parts of the game. 

OVERALL>>>>>>>>57%
Objectively not a good game. The core game is decent enough but the devs havn't given players anything new and substantial for years. The mechanics are questionable, the graphics are plain bad and the sound is average. This game prides itself on its database and simulation but that has been largely unchanged for nearly a decade. The only reason why you would buy the newest FB manager is to get a updated database which doesn't justify the price. No real reason for players of older versions to get this one but if you are football mad, like management games and haven't bought any older FB manager games then it would definitely be worth a try.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Tried to play Vanarama South league with a mid table team.
Can't figure out how to get my team to stop passing the ball to my opposition.
Gave the whole team passing training. Staff tells me teams completed their training.
Continues to go 0-3 against bottom table teams. 
I'm sure it's me... but after 50 hours of this, i'm done getting angry watching these simulated matches. Screaming at my screen for the defenders to mark their man (ya know, "use tighter markings") and stop leaving gaps and giving them so much space to move the ball. Instead they stand there, don't defend, don't cover, just watch the striker dribble past and take an open shot at goal.
Fine, maybe my team will dribble past when its our turn at ball.
Wait... No? We're just gonna boot it down the field?? Right into the opposition's feet? Of course we are we had training to make sure our passing was better.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
What can I say? I have thousands of hours logged for the Football Manager series, and have been playing since CM3. 

Fantastically in-depth, fully immersive and a real time-sink. Probably my most-played series of all time, and the latest version is great. You'll want to download the real badges, player faces etc. for the full experience, but you won't regret it. Probably the most bang for your buck you'll get out of a game if you're a football fan, and a bit of a control freak ;)

Anyway, this game stills stuck in old IA defects (I mean, like the previous versions).

For example, you are going to play a very important game in the Champions League, and suddenly all your team gets injuries. All season without bad injuries and suddenly you can't play with ur prefer players. 
Right now, I'm playing with SL Benfica and going to play against Arsenal in the Quarter-finals of the Champions League, and I get FIVE players injuries in the last two weeks: 4 of them are players from my starting team, including mine goalkeeper! Arsenal has zero injuries. I don't know how this can be called "realistic". 
For FM2020, playing with a Portuguese team against Mahrez, Ozil, Aubameyang, and Lacazete it's not enough, they need injurie half of your team...! What a j-o-k-e.
If you are comfortable in your national league (1st) and you want to make a good CL, this can be a lost season. Saying in another way, losing my precious time. 

You can say all these injuries it's "bad luck", but we all know it's not. This happens frequently in the biggest season games. It's basically the IA being biased in a very silly way and calling you retarded...  I play this kind of games since CM and can easily identify some patterns.

For sure I could say more things about FM2020, some positive and others negative, but the way they use AI to bias the game it's already enough to understand what you can expect.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Having been a regular FM player for a number of years, its sad to see it become like this. A match engine with a seemingly endless ability to frustrate you with flaws, 'player errors' and comical graphics. A transfer system that is skewed heavily in favour of the AI. A manager 'rating system' that bears no resemblance to a managers performance as well as the inability to alter club beliefs. All of which SI has been aware of in previous versions but, it seems, would rather focus their efforts on Regen personal circumstances and their own interpretation of Brexit. Sports Interactive have learned from FIFA, in all the worst ways. Churn out a game that is marginally different to the previous one (with bugs that subsequently require multiple versions to correct for the next 6 months), charge full price... voila. 

TL;DR - stick to FM14/15.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Broken match engine. Strikers cannot score, wingers do not cross, penalties galore. Fullbacks do not cross, inside forwards blast the ball into side netting 4-7 times a game every game. No ground trough balls.. BUutT itS JuST YOuR TaCTiCs BroOO

EDIT: As of February update the game is much better. All of the issues above have been resolved for the most part. Here are some additional issues I've noticed: 

The game tends to favor gegen pressing heavily, good luck sitting deep and trying to defend (although may be my tactics) 

Wingers and Fullbacks tend to blast the ball in a for a cross off defenders frequently, even though instructed to cross less often and playing narrow system. 

Annoying amount of offsides being shown on comprehensive highlights, since there is no instruction to tell the players to be more careful why show them over and over to me? 

Defenders frequently head/kick the ball out for a corner when they could clear it elsewhere

There is a glitch that allows you to sell your player for any sum you want (right click after offer accepted and type in whatever price you wish) 

Some of the descriptions are not written very clearly in what they do and how they impact the team, may be tough for new players to get into the game. Example, mentality should be rebranded as risk. 

Match sideline shouts are broken and/or not explained clearly in what they are supposed to do. Basically only demand more, praise (when up a goal), and get creative work, the rest just make my team lose focus for no reason. 

Despite the issues above I can now recommend the game.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Well, is there something to be said about this game people don't already know. 

It's a game you love to hate, hate to love, love to love and hate to hate at the very same time. I am pretty familliar with football as a sports, but I wouldn't call myself exactly a fanatic. But this game (and serial in general) is something I can't let go out of my hands. It does have that certain level of simulation value, where you can see what could happen, how would something look in certain conditions and it does always make sense.

Not only that, but it's the only game in this world which brings me to the very top and the very next game slams me down right into the ground. To a non-FM player it's pretty hard to explain how it feels when your regional club manages to snatch a draw against a club like Real Madrid in Champions League only to suffer a humbling defeat against a last placed club in your domestic league the very next game. And it's like a d*ug, you just can't let it go. 
When it goes good, you can't drop the game because you are on a roll, when it's bad you can't drop the game because you're not just some sissy that's giving up when times get rough.

This game can really drive you insane. Wroom wroom.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Addicting game. If you are not sure on the price, you can try the free demo that have full game feature that allows you to play through more than half of a season. The progress you made in demo can be transferred to the main game if you wanna buy it.

Really fun management sandbox game where you can go genocide mode and treat everyone bad, leak board meetings to press and get fired. Unemployed and have to suffer in bottom tier teams to climb your way up. I did that and now I'm one my way to making it to playoffs with the bad team. Building reputation on the way.

Highly recommended if you like managing and watching your team grow.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Having started playing FM since 09, I've seen the series evolve over time. You can see that the creators have tried to add more and more content to make it as absorbing and immersive as possible. 

Unfortunately it's let down by being structurally broken for one simple reason. The tactics and match engine are appalling. It takes away from everything else, as you feel you can't link what you have instructed the team to do vs what they are doing, and more importantly, what the opposition do. 

If you press, they half-arse it, the opposition dance round you and score. If you sit back, the opposition pass round you and score. Your players can't or seemingly choose not to tackle, meaning the opposition will literally run by your defenders like they're not there whilst your player stands still and lets them by. Your team cannot mark an opposition player in any situation and do not win any defensive second balls

This would actually all be forgivable if the opposition suffered the same flaws as you. However, this is FM so they don't. If you decide to get everyone behind the ball because you're fed up of watching your team not even try to defend, then whoever you're playing will score multiple 25 yard strikes to the top corner - with no correlation to their long shots and technique stats. If you try and engage in any way, well whoever has the ball becomes Messi incarnate and will happily run past multiple defenders to score  - again, with no correlation to their dribbling and finishing. I won't mention your team's inability to finish clear and half chances vs the opposition for my own sanity

The game strikes me as the latest window dressing in a series that needs a fundamental overhaul

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I like the concept of the game. However, I don't like how they've made this game more difficult over the years and also taken away the unrealistic stuff that you can take advantage of, wheres kept the unrealistic stuff that make the game difficult.
For example, youth intake is different, something you can't take advantage of (unrealistic stuff taken away that can be taken advantage of).
Another example, your players moaning about not having enough players in the squad and giving me only 7 days to make transfers. You can't do that in 7 days, so what happens is you have an unhappy player.
Another example, players in english non-league, who are free signing wanting over 20k per week. WTF is with that? 
I have the media chats, they've been the same for years now. It's boring.
Also a lack of flexibility when talking to players about problems, they won't accept 9/10 of the stuff that you say and then get an unhappy player.
Previous years I have enjoyed, however this I haven't. I didn't mind the unrealistic stuff, but the game is unbalanced in the way, where the unrealistic stuff that make the game difficult, don't change, but the exploits do. 
If your going to be a fair game, then take all this crap out, not just some of it.
I think I will be leaving for game for a few years, hoping they iron out some of these elements that make the game less realistic, which make the game more difficult to play.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I'm in mid March of my first season and I still have to play matches every week. This game is so unrealistic.

In all seriousness though, the match engine is a disaster-class. 

Bang average at best players employ their 10-11 dribbling skill to run past 3 world class defenders on the regular.

You get 1-2 goals disallowed and 3-4 shots hitting the post literally every game. 

Mediocre goalkeepers manage to parry 15-20 shots per game while their equally mediocre forward teammates convert 2 out of 3.

15+ marking defenders make it a point to leave opposing players completely alone, instead marking their own teammates.

Defenders pull off sliding tackles on their own teammates in their own box, but absolutely refuse to attempt tackles on opponents advancing towards their goal.

And speaking of sliding tackles, on the off-chance someone actually performs one on an opponent, the ball only moves about 5 cm so the tackled player shrugs, picks it up again and continues his run. That's not how physics work, SI!

This game actually makes me miss FIFA manager...

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Understandably, as someone who has clocked up roughly 8,500 hours playing the FM series thus far from CM00/01 to the current iteration, I'd like to think I know what makes a good Football Manager game and what has historically let the series down. FM20 does the best job of any instalment so far of improving and expanding on the good and dealing with the negatives.

The match engine is fantastic. Players move in a convincing way; stepovers, Cruyff turns, stop-and-go, all represented here in the best match engine to date. Yes the crowd animations are repetitive but you know what, if you want to play FIFA, go and play FIFA.

The IMMENSE scale of the game means you might feel overwhelmed by your responsibilities and the sheer amount of clicking you need to do to establish your latest season but please, friend, worry not! Along with all these new options comes a wealth of new staff responsibilities, and you can delegate or take charge at your leisure, Like to finalise signings but don't really care about the scouting side of things? Delegate it. Prefer to find those hidden gems yourself but couldn't care less about negotiating their contracts? Sure, delegate it. Want to keep an eye on your blossoming U23 side but the U18s are just too far off your radar right now? Guess what? Delegate it.

I haven't been this impressed with the advances in a Football Manager title since FM13, everything you can think of that would improve the series from FM19 is here. Data presentation is fantastic, player development and progression is as close to perfection as it could be. FM20 makes the complicated things seem simple and makes the simple things seem effortless. To me, this is now THE Football Manager title.

Simply put, FM20 is a defining moment in the history of Football Manager titles. Make no mistake, this one is a classic. Though you may not find the next Tonton Zola Mokouko sitting in Derby County's reserves, every story you do write for yourself on this genre-defining game will carry its own memories and legacy and surely that is the highest praise of all.

Ps. Match engine is still sometimes a bit of a joke

Takes a little while to grasp everything that's going on (would recommend watching youtube videos to figure some of it out) but very fun once you get the hang of it. 10/10 would recommend

title: Football Manager 2020
review:

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Likes:
- Football Manager - probably the greatest sports management sim franchise ever developed
- Lots of competitions and players to consider (including International teams)
- Decent AI (not too difficult so new players like me can actually play and win some games right away)
- Watching my team execute my custom tactics in wonderful 3D Extended Highlights
- Having the ability to hire the right supporting staff to reduce all the micromanagement required in running your clubs (first squads, youths, and academy) and makes the game faster
- Fully customizable game database
- Solid In-game Editor with the option to deactivate it for the purists

Dislikes:
- Technical Issue: One (1) Fatal Crash To Desktop experienced so far during the halftime of my Unemployed Career game (forum discussion suggests possible fatal issue with NVIDIA graphics cards). I hope the crash did not corrupt my save file...
- TONS and TONS of menus in game. It can be overwhelming to someone who's not used to FM games
- I notice that my days are going by so fast
- TONS and TONS of menus in game. Several features (like managing Youth leagues and your Academy) are only accessible via it's own tiny clickable button inside another menu that may be easily missed.
- I have suffered many sleepless nights so far since I installed the game
- Have I already mentioned that there are TONS and TONS of menus in game? I wish the next FM game would have a simpler UI.

Nonetheless, it's still worth the purchase (especially when it goes on Sale) !!! :D

Verdict: Totally Recommended, even if you're not a fan of Football (or soccer, depending where you're from) but enjoy business sim or tycoon type of games. Fair Warning: This game might convert you into an actual Football fan...

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
FM 20 is the alarming case, when SI releases two versions of the the game consecutively worse than the previous one. FM 19 was an attempt to overhaul tactical side of the game and quite expectedly many changes didn't go too well, resulting in inconsistent Match Engine, where player simply can't see results of his choices, because intructions fail to apply. It was understandable and I hoped these issues would be fixed next year. They were not, in fact they got even worse.

Completely unrealistic chance coversions, GKs never following instructions, wingers mindlessly hitting balls when there are two open teammates in the box, nerfed strikers, passive counter mentality, you name it. Adding this to already existing problems like neverchanging interviews, interactions with useless options, unbalanced transfer market, stale world simulation and overestimated reputation effect, and you get the clear sign that SI have stopped paying attention to players feedback. We don't really need loan manager or any other fancy roles, when DoF is still useless, here's your example

Now don't get me wrong, I'm still a fan and FM is my favourite addiction, but I see 19 as a failed step forward and 20 is worse than 19. I'll keep playing, but I'm concerned that series are going backwards, and devs are applying cosmetic changes to a stale team management, in the meantime messing up match engine more and more. Eventually this might hurt them

Cutting to the chase, if you pick top club and apply plug and play tactics, you'l have a blast and win things. If your FM experience is playing for underdogs, developing club and tinkering with tactics and scouting, you might be up for a frustrating experience

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Great attention to detail on the game. However, i feel that the game has moved backwards in terms of realism. Understood that away days would generally be more difficult than home games however making bottom of the league teams level contenders with top of the league teams in terms of possession and chances is too unrealistic. The new addition of random goals being scored out of absolutely nowhere with no build up has on occasion made me want to smash my computer, this isn't necessary and adds nothing positive to the game.
Can honestly say that in the past ten games played, opposition GK have had unrealistically good performances. Expected on the odd game but not every game.
The better your team gets, the harder the game makes it which is great as it continues making the game challenging however, is also unrealistic in ways of world class strikers going from scoring 40 goals a season to not being able to put the ball past a bottom of the league keeper.

The game is highly addictive but unfortunately, there are more negatives to the gameplay than positives. The majority of the above have always been the case with fm games but with FM20 it is clear that these negatives have become a bigger part of the game.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I used to buy FM every year since CM93.  Nowadays I only buy FM every other year because of the minor improvements and I always wait for the summer sale, not because I'm tight but because most of the problems have been ironed out by then.  This year, as always, there is a new look and feel to FM, it has taken me about 40 hours to get used to it but I have to say, I like it, it feels more immersive, you feel closer to your players with better interactions than previous versions, they've actually put some new text choices in to things like the "Press Conference" amongst other things and I'd say its about time too.
The thing that really immerses me in the game is the 3D Match Engine, for me, its the part where you get to see all your hard work pay off (or fail) and unfortunately, there isn't much of an improvement in that regard.  Its ok, as it was last year and the year before but it could really do with being better quality than it is.  Don't get me wrong here, I love FM20 but you would think that 3-4 years down the line, it might actually look a bit more improved than it is.
The other thing that irks me, and I'm sure, many others is that on release, FM always has many problems, bugs, errors etc..  They have a whole year to get it right, why do they release a game at +£40 and then take 6 months to make it playable?  It makes people mad every year, with the money they suck out of us each year, you'd think that SEGA/FM would offer a more polished product on release.  I'd happily pay full price every year if there were improvements that worked out of the box.
That said, I'm happy with my £20 purchase and I like the new layout, FM20 is a good game (now) and well worth the price, it'll give any football fan many hours of replayable headaches and nightmares, just like real football.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I waited a very long time between games to try a new FM; my last game was FM15, which I got a lot of time out of.

I feel like a lot of the changes that have occurred since then have been to the detriment of QoL, and a lot of the interfaces are now more obtuse to navigate.  I also feel that the tactics screen and sliders and so-forth are less impactful on play than they perhaps have been in FM generations past, but that may be because the interface changes just don't sit well with me.  So much of this game feels like changing a winning formula not for the sake of change, but to try to attract new players to the game as if a slightly more modern tactics screen and a less functional scouting page would entice new people to play a very autistic spreadsheet simulator game.  

The only reason I don't regret my money spent per se is that now seeing my investment in this game as a waste of money, I've begun to move on from these infinite-replayability games that don't accomplish anything but suck away precious time in my life from doing things that are actually enriching or enjoyable.  In a roundabout way, thank you, SI.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Yes i would recommend it but only just! 

i have loved footy manager ever since champ man 08, and this years has me right on the fence! i love the in depth detail you can go into this year, i also like the fact that you can farm all those time consuming details out to other members of your staff if you want a more streamlined experience! scouting feels better this year and so does training, you really do feel like your players improve in aspects your focusing on and in positional changes.  HOWEVER.......the game engine graphics haven't really changed in years and that is so disappointing, still okay but at this stage in fifa 14 graphics would feel like a huge step forward..... my main issue and the one that really has me on the fence about even continuing playing is the lack of consistency and darn right infuriation of the ai match engine, i dont get it, i really dont. I can sim a whole league with my custom arsenal tactics and i will the league by a landslide, aubameyang and lacazette  score goals for fun 20/30 a season, play this identical team & tactics yourself manually and you get an average rating of 6.4 no goals from either of them and suddenly Bournmouth have become Barcelona tika taka passing through my whole team and scoring goals for fun, i go from a league winning side to relegation fodder and the only change is the AI match engine, sort it out it makes me not want to play or sim the majority of the games!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
What can I say about this game, I have such mixed feelings about this.

First off, this might arguably be the best FM in terms of all the control and freedom it provides to you, with a slightly better UI and performance. However the thing that really goes against the game is the match engine, which is, well, horrendous to put it mildly. It has been getting worse over the past few years but, this might just be the worse one. I really don't know what I can add that hasn't already been covered in countless other reviews.

I love FM, I've played like 10 different editions of this game, but if you have FM 19, or even 18, I wont recommend buying this game. Rather download editor data and update transfers than buying this game.  Hopefully Sega listens to the community and fixes the game engine next year because this has been going on for 2-3 editions now.
