title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I bought this game in the sale and it is a worthwhile purchase. I generally buy Football Manager games every 3-4 years because sometimes they are not so different. I am coming up from FM 2017.

The best thing about this game is that the graphics are a little better when playing a match. Player animations are clearer and the ball really curves now when shots are taken. Nothing major but it does make for a better playing experience. I also like the addition of the Video Assistant Referee. 

Obviously, the game has updated players and this is another big advantage when you want to use players that are at your club now (especially if your team in real-life has improved!). 

The interface is quite loud and a bit confusing for me. I preferred FM 2017 because it was simpler and cleaner. However, you do get used to it and over time it becomes easier to find out where things are and how to adjust settings. I recommend increasing the text size.

The gameplay has also been updated to include 'gegenpressing' and other tactics. It just makes an already good game better and it is worth getting it in the sale! 8/10.

*For FM 2021, I would like to see goal-line technology and VAR replays shown on your screen.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I play a lot of games but have never wrote a review. 

I'm really loving this version of Football Manager. I also own FM 2014. The game has come quite a way since then. I really love games that give me the control to build and manage all aspects of a team. FM 2020 gives me everything I need. I'm currently playing this over another game I really enjoy (The Division 2). I just get so much enjoyment for what I look for in games. Hope this helps then next person make their decision. Cheers!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I'm gonna have to give this a thumbs down. 5 years ago someone gifted me FM15 and I was hooked, even bought the game through key stores ever since because it wasn't available in my country.

But honestly almost nothing has changed. The match engine is laughably bad at this point. And that's not just because the graphics look like absolute shit but because it is super scripted. Sometimes the game seems to tell the match engine "I need team A to score now" and then out of nowhere the wildest combination of passes and mistakes happen which lead to a bullshit goal. You don't feel like you are in charge. So often your defenders just let the enemy run through, so often your goalkeeper makes an obvious mistake and so often your striker just kicks it out of the stadium.

Every year they promise an improved match engine but every year it is a letdown. Also almost every year the match engine is broken for the first few months. The only reason I still sometimes play it is because there's no alternative. But once there is a serious competitor I'm off to something else. It's a shame.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
It's OK adding pointless extras like social media, which in my opinion is one reason why football is heading down the toilet, but until they address the pathetic match engine it will never improve. Same story as every other incarnation - having 30-40 shots per game and failing to score more than a couple of goals, whereas opposition score from almost every chance, inexplicable decision making, clunky wooden player movements.... same old, same old.

Still, when idiots like me continue to buy it, they don't need to invest to improve it, do they?!

I get that it is a simulation game, and its about the strategy not the graphics. But nothing that happens when you watch the game is reflective of the instructions given to players, so it would be better to remove the match simulation if they aren't willing to improve it. 'Run at defence', 'hit early crosses', 'cross from deep' may as well be removed, because the players never do any of them. A personal favourite is seeing your player shoot (usually from a ridiculous angle) and it gets blocked by a defender, then ricochets back into your own six yard box!! Are these players made out of concrete?!

The decisions players make are laughable; apparently world class players shooting from impossible angles, hitting shots straight at the goalkeeper instead of squaring it to an unmarked team-mate, and playing suicide passes across the front of their back four are evident numerous times in every game.

Aside from the match engine, there is also very little scope for digging out a bargain. In FM19, it was possibly too easy to pick up young, cheap players who would go on to become stars, but this version has gone to the other extreme. You find a half-decent youngster playing for a village team in Nigeria, and his club want £25m for him. Again, they just can't get the balance right. 

What is desperately required is a rival game, ideally made by people who understand football. The makers of FM have become lazy and complacent as despite how bad the game continues to be, there is very little competition in this space.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: This game is incredible. The level of detail and attempt at realism the creators have managed to put into it is what makes it the great game it is. You learn so much about the sport on all fronts: the different roles of the players, staff responsibilities, negotiation and leadership skills, and a whole lot more, and the diversity of leagues you can manage in gives you a great perspective on world football in general. This is the closest thing to a real manager job available. One thing I hope is included is the North African leagues which are all top African leagues that have a significant number of the continent's most decorated teams, and a save in one of them I believe would be a good experience.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:

You're going to spend 10's of hours doing technical junk on your computer and then on the next update you're just going to go from crashing randomly while playing to not even being able to load the game. 

FANTASTIC WASTE OF MONEY - NOT BUILT TO RUN ON MODERN WINDOWS SYSTEMS!!!!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
It's a few years since I played Football Manager extensively. What I can say, over 800 hours into FM2020 is it's well worth a play. Yes you still get 'FM'd' on occasion, and yes that's incredibly frustrating. But I've also nicked a 1-0 when I've been comprehensively outplayed on a fair few occasions.   

Having skipped the last couple of iterations, FM2020 felt like a new experience for me, the team dynamics, the training and the new ways of scouting all enhanced my gameplay and you can really feel the difference in the game engine when you employ different styles of football. Wing Play for example compared with Tika-Taka shows very differently in a match environment. 

My latest save, with York City, has been an amazing journey from the bottom to the premier league and this is the beauty of Football Manager, in my opinion, it allows you to experience fantasy (York will unlikely ever be in the premier league) but grounds it in reality so you get the satisfaction of your achievement.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
In summary - a brilliant game let down by a less than adequate match engine.

Having logged nearly 500 hours and played through 9 seasons, unfortunately I cannot look beyond the glaring issues on match day any longer. Ultimately, the higher up the divisions you go, the more frustrating the match engine gets.

Cons - 

1. One on ones are completely broken. You will find that in the lower leagues the problem may not be as prevalent due to awful goalkeeping being a regular occurrence, but once you reach the top divisions, keepers are impossible to beat or your player misses the target 99 times out of 100. The AI misses chances too, but let's not ignore a fundamental flaw. I think the missed chances are relating to match engine balancing - it is too easy to generate one-on-one situations so the conversion rate is kept artificially low by dreadful finishing.  

2. Set pieces are far too powerful, leading to a myriad of goals. Penalties and goals scored from direct free kicks are realistic, but corners and indirect free kicks are too bigger source of goals.

3. Inexcusably, the set piece creator does not mirror what is seen on match day, so you have a game which doesn't replicate the instructions you have assigned in this area. This can lead to conceding goals that otherwise would not have been conceded. Specifically, throw ins are a complete farce and need a rethink from the developers. You cannot have one throw in instruction for defending and one for attacking, it needs to be split into four sections - the defensive quarter near your own goal, two quarters either side of the halfway line and the attacking quarter near the opponents goal. 

4. Goal variety - set piece, cross followed by a back post header from a winger, long shot, winger dribbling 50 yards into the area and an occasional error. I can count on one hand how many times I've witnessed a central midfielder assist via a through ball. There needs to be a complete overhaul of movement in the opposition's half to generate a more fulfilling goal variety.

Pros -      

1. Everything outside of the match engine, seriously. Massive kudos to the development team here as the games feels very polished and rewarding. 
 
This edition is the equivalent of playing GTA's story all the way to the end, then for a big screen to pop up saying they didn't get a chance to finish the final mission. Damn.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Game has stagnated for the past few years. ME is plagued with bugs from release, and the game MAY be playable by the last patch in March. That is if the devs get their act together and pull their finger out and focus their attention to all aspects of the game. ME animations are still sub par and looks like something you would find in Actua Soccer 99. Its not all about the graphics, but the animations make it look much worse. Furthermore, the ME is buggy. Far too many one on ones via long through balls, players hardly cross anymore, the ME just feels linear and is a joke to put simply

Posted numerous bug reports but I am officially done. Nothing gets done and im fed up. The developers are far too apathetic and egotistic and are in another world. The game is no where near good enough; compare the ME too FM12 and FM14. Those were much better IMO. Im not sure what planet the devs are on or what they smoke, but their behaviour and attitude needs plenty of work. The game feels like it was made by a bunch of amateurs, and clearly it has been. Tiny studio with no many resources and it clearly depicts this with the final product. Mr Brock states he wants the ME to become as close as real life as possible. I would love to know what he puts in his tea. Firstly. the match sounds have been the same for over 15 years, and CM01/02 had better sounds. Animations still pathetic, grass still looks crappy and to prove they're a joke, they release SNOW as a new feature, but cant even get it right. Have you seen how sloppy and pathetic it looks. And one of the devs quoted that it is a feature they are working on and it will get better in future versions. Are they having a laugh?? Dont release something that looks like a grade one student just drew. It literally looks like a couple white blobs my niece jotted on a piece of paper. Disgusting and just shows the state of the game and the ME at present. Pitch marks look like black dots and are pixelated and reminds me of Doom from the mid 90s.

Overall very very disappointed with the lack of progress, especially with the ME, which is their bread and butter. AI squad building still very very bad, and its relatively easy to build a champion team with pretty much any side, because the AI pulls of spastic moves and is nowhere near good enough to build a good squad. AI needs to loan much better players (lower leagues) and just improve drastically. 

I am not a member of their forums as I have been told that whatever you post, the moderators over there are quick to pounce on negativity which is surprising as I thought they were super helpful and bug reporting would assist in improving the game, but apparently SI have swept so many issues and bugs from previous versions and have yet to rectify them, and just provide a band aid fix. Example? Players hardly ever cross, where as in the previous 2-3 versions, you may as well have called it Crossing and Microsoft Excel simulator. That is how it felt. 

I highly suggest you hold off buying the game, or at least try out the demo and find out for yourself.
Too late for me to get a refund, but will definitely not buy the game for the next 3-4 years as they simply dish out the same garbage every year,. and the game is not playable up until March at the very least, and that is IF they fix the issues

FM19 was a joke as strikers were pretty much useless in the game, and guess what? SI never fixed the issues at all, so the game was pretty much broken for its entire life span. How useless is that. If you are a casual FM player and dont pay attention to these issues and dont care, sure, buy the game. But if you have purchased the last 12 games, and are a hardcore player who wants realism and immersion, do not buy the game right now. It will give you PTSD and anxiety from all the bugs and hair pulling. Potentially great game designed by a small obscure studio with poor facilities without undersoil heating and poor research facilities. 

EDIT: Here in May, and ME is broken. Small bug like the net bulging when the ball hits it was listed as a bug in January, and was never fixed. Devs are apathetic towards the game. DO NOT BUY  a game where the devs dont even care put their heart in it.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I have played many iterations of this game, and find this version to be uniquely frustrating.
If you play as a big club, I think you will have a whale of a time.
But as a smaller club, there are insurmountable barriers to success.
I have spent a few seasons in Premiership mediocrity after promotion with Nottingham Forest, and the conundrum is this:
Every time I try to buy very talented players to help take me to the next level, they very quickly, and without fail, throw their toys out of the pram, demand this or that impossible sum of money, the squad morale goes down the toilet, and I lose game after game, until the only way I can steady the ship is to sell the player. This is not just the case with established world class players: even youngsters I sign at 18, after their first breakthrough season on a meagre wage, become world class divas the next season and steady the ship.

So my options: to carry on with mediocre squad players and stay in mid-table until I eventually get sacked––or buy the wonderkids and precipitate my downfall that way.

For the people who are sceptical: i got to a point in my game where a wonderkid (on 20k per week) rejected my contract offer of 150k per week + bonuses, all of the squad decided *he* had been unfairly treated and had low morale, and i had a game coming up against the 17th place team in bad form. i played this one game 8 different times, using different tactics and team-talks, and lost every time. The odds are impossibly stacked against you if you have just one big-time charlie in your team!

Increased player power is a reality in the modern game. But it shouldn't get to the point where one player is able to scupper the entirety of the game!

-bottom teams play like Barca and beat you
-competitors thrashed the same opponents that beat you
-get scored against in dying minutes, several times (I once conceded 3 goals in stoppage time to lose a game)
-players getting unhappy for stupid reasons (too many don't wanna list all)
-AI wants a premium from you for their players and offer 5m for your 50m valued player and ask you to pay 50% of his wages
Highly recommend this game to anyone who thinks all of the above are realistic because "it happens in real life" and "you just need to get good".

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
As of the release date (today), the game is in need of several updates to fix the bugs, stuttering, errors, crashing etc. That a game is allowed to be released before it is a finished product and have people purchase it for real hard earned money is criminal. The game runs and the core elements work, though several things do not. Those several things are what makes a person upgrade from the previous iteration. People pay for the new instalment under the impression that it will be better than the previous...an improvement. Unfortunately, as of the release date which happens to be today, the game have several things yet to be fixed which sadly ruin the immersion of the gaming experience. Every time I face one of these bugs, I understandably become frustrated and lose interest. I understand that the bugs will be ironed out over the coming weeks, though until then I cannot recommend 2020 over 2019.

UPDATE: Updates have improved the game and its stability, though several features have gone overlooked despite several mentions within the game forum. Features that were highlighted during the release of the game remain broken and neglected. For a game that is released every year with few major upgrades, it is surprising that so many bugs should exist.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The gameplay and match engine is frustrating, annoying, and a lot of times unrealistic and doesn't make any sense. 
I've tried everything I possibly could but for some reason I cannot control possession to save my life. By the way, I am the Bayern Munich manager playing against the likes of Union Berlin or Hamburg or Zwickau and they dominate the game which is the closest thing to impossible that I can think of. I am dropping points to so many draws because for 60 percent of the match I am chasing the ball. The opposition always loves to knock the ball around with no purpose to their passing, just playing keep away, back to their goalie and whatnot and when I finally do get the ball I lose it just as quick as I gained it. Because of this I have a really good defensive record and a low scoring rate. 
Also scoring sometimes is garbage. I used to only be able to score long range goals from outside the box but now I can't do that anymore. I would even miss obvious clear cut chances that non-pros would make an absolute living off of because the ball doesn't want to or isn't allowed to hit the back of the net.
The gameplay is the most important component of the game and if it's this poor in my opinion, what do you really have? Is it really worth buying this game? 
Besides that I really love the game. Everything is top notch from top to bottom. It is so detailed and fun to manage your club that I find myself playing it all the time. Honestly, I can get over the licensing issues or just find mods online to download. It's just matchdays that I absolutely dread. I almost wish I was not the head coach but rather only another staff member just so I wouldn't have to stress about tactics that are completely useless and just enjoy the other really good components of this game. 

Update: After playing this garbage some more, I wish i never bought it. Every good thing I said before i take it back because this game is terrible. So frustrating how unrealistic and stupid this all is. I can't deal with this extremely poor match engine where none of your tactics even matter or affect the outcome of the game because its already set even way before the match starts. This match engine alone ruins the whole game and like I said before, if the match engine is this bad, you literally have a worst of the worst game because nothing else good matters. I hate this game so much. I just hope everyone sees this comment before they go wasting their money better spent on something meaningful.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
If you love sports and you love simulation games, football manager is as good as it gets.  If you haven't played the series, you are missing out.  Think football (or soccer in America) doesn't make sense or you don't know the game.  It doesn't really matter.  This game has the deepest database, most realistic simulation (in-game and over multiple seasons) and gives you the depth of running a whole organization.

The 2020 version is the best and most realistic yet.  The youth development and planning portion of the game is the best yet.  The ability to sign and develop youth has long been most gamer's favorite parts of the series.  The added depth in this version takes it to a new level.  

I greatly enjoy building a team from scratch, developing youth into world class footballers and making waves in the transfer market.  People have complained about the match engine.  I am yet to see an issue.  I think those complaining have never watched a real game and seen the same things happen.

I would try to get the game on sale but would pay full price for it (especially if you don't already have one of the series).  You will not be disappointed.  There is no feeling like trouncing your rival to win the championship for your league or in a cup game.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Don't buy. Absolute waste of time. Match engine is still broken as it was all these years. Nothing changed. My last buy was 2016. Decided to purchase this one bcz of positive feedback. Only to see that players at England Championship level doing things that in real life you'll not see from player at League two level. Defenders will kick the ball to coner whenever they meet the ball near the back line. Strikers and wingers will try to score from impossible angles instead of passing the ball across. AI will score in added time every fourth/fifth game while you will score a goal in last minutes once a season. Defenders  stay cool while opposite striker paves his way for the shot. Keeper throwing the ball directly to the opposite striker leg - how often you see this in real life? Maybe once a season, here, in FM it happens frequent (remember we're talking about Championship level players)... and a lot of other ridiculous things that I just have no time to describe here...Don't get me wrong, there are a lot of cool stuff around the match, but when it comes to the match itself the gameplay is ruined...This is my last buy of this series

New update: Forget about broken match engine. The entire game is broken. At one day, after you've worked hard to bring your team to where you are, the game will start crashing with 
"FM 2020 encoutered  a serious problem and will close" message. You'll not be able to load this save anymore. Then after going back to a very old save,  one day, out of the blue, the game will start crashing with "FM 2020 stopped working (staging) and will close". No recover from this... DO NOT BUY.

review:
It's just the same rehashed crap as last few years. As soon as you set mentality to attacking/overload, the clock runs down with nothing happening. 1v1's? Guaranteed the striker misses every time regardless of his stats. Goal being reviewed by VAR = offside every time...HAS THERE EVER BEEN ONE THAT WAS ACTUALLY GIVEN?? I put a fully fit, star studded team against a Vanarama North squad. And set it to full attack. Result? 1-0. with 3 highlights the entire game. 

Usual stats - 60+% possession, 25+ shots, 0 goals. No matter the formation/squad.

Seriously Devs, take a year out, and actually produce something new that makes it special again. 

And since installing, I have had 3 save game corruptions where I've lost everything and had to start again.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The best football simulator game I ever seen. The mechanics oriented on club and team management rather than actual game day, which is amazing.
Highlighting 3 core strengths of the game:
- The spectrum of actions you can take
- Realism
- Actual football knowledge is a game changer (in a good way)
Key Weakness:
- Some users find it a difficult game mechanics to learn (not me)
 
What to recommend for future?
- Develop Financial System so the player can influence more on expenses and income
- Make conversations located in specific place (so when player talks to team in half-time or gets a press release we could actually spectate some sort of image or action zone in dressing room/press hall and etc)
- More customisation tools and at least fake named sponsors who will add realism to names, stadiums and etc.

In addition 2) the legal limitations to be able to download correct 3D kits (and other graphical elements) is completely ruining the game for me. It'll be OK this year as the previous seasons kits work in the game, but for FM21 it just won't be the same to play the game without all the grapichal enhancements. I do get the legal issues here, but they are killing the game - for me at least. I just can't play the game with fake kits, logos, names, etc. Hoping for some sort of solution or work-arround.

review:
I assumed everyone was exaggerating how flawed the match engine is but they weren't. It really lets down what should have been a thoroughly enjoyable game. 

90% of goals are from corners and free kicks. you could create 18 chances in a game with 5 one on ones and the opposition keeper will save it all. sounds like an exaggeration right... same thing I thought.

 I played one season till october i.e 3 months and I couldn't stomach anymore. it's the 1st FM game I'm quitting and not going back to. these things used to be addictive. the Match Engine was heaven in 03/04 and just kept getting progressively worse. I think the last good one i played was 2012..

I won't recommend this to anyone. It's been over 8 months since this game was released and if these errors have not been fixed in that time then the creators just don't care anymore.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: So far been playing it for near a whole day of game time and I've encountered a couple annoying issues, those being save game failed and a flickering white screen when a match starts which I was able to correct by restarting the game and taking the screen out of full screen into windowed respectively, but I've been massively enjoying the focus on tactics and immersion which counteracts any negatives. The  match animations, although can be clumsy, is respectable and from what I've gathered only the heart pounding moments are played out in slow which makes them truly fun. So far the majority of my experience has been of a national team under 19s. Only thing I can add that may be an improvement is a reason as to why a player would retire early, like a 16 year old whose been called up to the national squad, or the inability to call up a player who wasn't manually removed. There's already so much depth in this game. Definitely recommend this to anybody that wants a full experience in a game rather than just do a couple things and match time.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: the game is addictive, which is what you want... however, the game engine is so unfortunately poorly constructed.... you will find yourself losing games that your team is clearly better, but not once... all the time. the teams with 2 shots on target will regularly draw or win a match..... two seasons in, my team is rarely losing a game where the team has less shots on goal, or was not dominant (meaning my team was better and still lost)... almost all of the games lost, my team was a a better team, had more shots, better GK, and then one shot on a goal, and a draw or a loss.... some games can be like that, not 15 in a season.... also, why is my team not winning games like that? Anyway, the game is frustrating as the real football season always is, but if we had 15 games where an EPL team keeper was the best player against your team, meaning the opposing GK had 10+ saves, you would say your forwards/strikers were not 4 or 5 stars, or even 3 stars.....

review:
Great game, although I can't believe that in FM 2020 we still don't have the following all-time fan favorites:

- a Photo-op before the start of the season. Do you remember the posters we all had in our rooms? The ones with all the players, staff and trophies that were won the previous season. I mean how hard it is to render a picture like that? SI, you have all the tools and brains for it, do not deny us such delights. Don't forget to list the player and staff names as well.

- You need to do a better work with the trophy room. Man, put some imagination or send people to see the trophy rooms of big European clubs. 

- make rivalries and derby games more dynamic and feed it to us as news. If I play 3 final or semi-final games for CL against the same team within 5 seasons, a rivalry could get established. Also, rivalries could get established from high profile transfers. Like Suarez and Coutinho going to Barcelona. Or when a larger team is feeding from a smaller team and buying off their players in bulk. Also there should be some push back against rich and big teams and i am not talking about financial fair play.  

- I am still waiting to play as a president/general manager of a club. I know it may sound boring, but it may not be. A lot of us play the game as presidents anyway. Who doesn't click on auto-pick, right? As a president you still have a lot to say about transfers, style of play, vision, etc. plus you will have to negotiate and find sponsors, contractors, staff but the biggest of all joys to get into the dressing room give pep talks or snap a selfie, lol. 
  *Plus, if you could start as a maintenance and grow through the ranks ;)

- And last but not least: Why not have friendly tournaments of indoor football with 6 players on the field? It could be even  for charity. Having those will keep players that are not on international duty sharp. 

I am telling you, if you add even only one of those to the game for next year, you will make a lot of people happy and make FM 2021 stand out a head above its predecessors and competitions.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This game can be incredibly frustrating and I do not believe that it warrants the full $50 price tag.  Don't get me wrong, as I have had enjoyable moments in the game, but those come less and less the longer I play.

First and most importantly, the ME is in need of work.  
-Strikers are often on the losing ends of 1v1s way too many times.  I don't know if this done to create some difficulty in the game, but it seems almost impossible to score off these chances.  
-Long shots are still a bit too prevalent in this game.
-Wingers and fullbacks do not cut back properly when striker is unmarked in box.
-Defenders seem to lack any sense of positioning when dealing with set-pieces.  
-Players do some weird animation when trying to prevent the ball from going out of bounds.  They manage to save it but then take a number of steps beyond the ball, allowing the opposition to gain possession.
-VAR is way too consistent in its decisions.  (ie if called in the box, it will always be a penalty.  If the referee goes to check for offsides, it will always be offside)
-Also, VAR sometime call an onside goal, offside (https://community.sigames.com/topic/520454-var-offside-issues/)  
- Also note that SI will not be updating the ME for FM2020 (https://community.sigames.com/topic/518591-thanks-for-all-the-feedback/) As a result, some of these known bugs/issues will not be resolved (which makes it somewhat a slap in the face that SI still is considering charging full price)

Second, AI transfers make no sense
-This is more of a gripe than a bug.  Players seem to make moves to other clubs that are either A) questionable or B) the teams would never sell normally.  You are telling me that Liverpool would willingly sell VVD to Paris for £60 million?  After a Champions League winning season in which he was a key player for the team?

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I moved Celtic and Rangers into the Vanarama so I can build something.  I've done this in multiple incarnations of this game, so I know to change nation to England, but somehow we are still in the Scottish League Cup (and group stage at that) which has added extra games.  Not a problem as it gave me a chance to field mainly promising U23s against lower league sides.
Including friendlies (four I think), I've played 22 games.  I've won 19, with the only defeat being away in the CL playoff, which I won anyway. One draw was in the League Cup group and another was away in a CL qualifier.  We've played one CL group match away to Galatasaray, and came from 2-0 down to win 3-2 and top a group with PSG.
Because of the extra matches from the league cup and Europe, we've only played five league matches, which have all been won with a goal difference of 21-1.  We are sitting 8th (only seven points behind) having played five games less than everyone else, and suddenly half my squad have lost faith in me because we are apparently struggling.  It's mainly key players as well who have all had a lot of game time.
Perhaps the game is great if you don't edit anything, but you'd think after 20 years of providing an editor, they'd have made the game engine smart enough to deal with odd situations that arise from using it.
I attempt to warn the main instigator about his conduct and he says he always conducts himself well on the pitch.  He has no idea the angry meeting has even taken place.
Add to that there seems to still be an awful lot of random injuries out of nowhere.  This lot don't seem to be getting any better at anything other than the 3D pitch.  Mind you, my wide players don't seem to be able to take anyone on.  They sprint to the last third, then slowly walk, then get tackled by a guy already lying on the ground.  That guy will then get up and get the ball whilst my guy stands around wondering where he is.
Corners don't go anywhere other than into the six yard box to be immediately cleared by a centre half.  Also, the camera angle for corners is horrific.  You can't tell whats happening.

So now I have Aberdeen at home in the league cup.  I've attended the prematch interview and one of the questions is "Aberdeen won't be used to visiting smaller stadiums like CELTIC PARK".  Seriously, Celtic Park, a smaller stadium than they are used to?  Get a f*****g grip SI.  Why give access to an editor if it is going to do stupid s**t like this.  Yes, I'm now in a lower league, but how can it not realise this?  Why does it look at the stature of the league instead of the actual club?

title: Football Manager 2020
review: This game definitely has the fundamentals of being a very successful game. It has a very select level of detail and does very well to simulate what a normal professional manager would go through day to day. However, there are some bugs that I would consider to be underground that can completely ruin the game. I'm not talking about problems with the match engine or club vision, I'm talking about a specific scenario that almost made it unable for me to continue the game. First and foremost, the club world cup in 2021 is hosted during late June, the period when all of your players are either on vacation or on international duty. When I got to this point when managing RB Leipzig, I was only allowed to train my players the week of my matches, and the game acted like all the players were unavailable to play when they were available. I was able to manage overall training, but I couldn't alter the players training intensity because they weren't training at all. After I played my first match, the match sharpness or conditions of my players weren't getting better (as they are usually terrible after a vacation) even though I had recovery sessions that they weren't attending. Even worse, the other team's players were recovering after each match which made the games totally unfair. I know the game is programmed in a way that makes everyone go on vacation during a certain period, but they don't make any compromises when there are tournaments like the Club World Cup that you have to play during that time. Please fix this and hopefully I'm not the only person that encountered this problem. This is a problem specific to Europeans teams that make it all the way to 2021. Thank you for reading up to this point and tell me if you also encounter this issue in 2021.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Played nearly 100 hours in two weeks. 

As someone completely new to FM, this game is absolutely fantastic. Sure there is some weird situations where a 1 on 1 opportunity seems to get blown, but overall the game plays correctly, and tiny changes in your tactics can make or break a big match. 

Been doing my run thru with Manchester City and after a very successful first season, we struggled behind Liverpool our second year, resulting in a few big transfers and a stronger focus on youth development. Now going into my third year we are boasting a strong winning streak, with Liverpool left in the dust, and our bitter rivals - Manchester United hot on our tails. 

The game creates a story in itself, the interviews get repetitive but still hold meaning even after the 20th time being asked the same question. Your team reacts to every word, and a slight drop in morale can cost your entire squad their form. 

Great game, and definitely worth the pick up. I wanted to get the game on sale but go figure I got it a week before it finally went on sale.. but I feel I already gained my moneys worth!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Liking the new additions although my save is early, excited to see how others pan out. Park kicks up nicely be awesome if the ball got affected by it. Will edit as I get my teeth into the new features. So far, so good.

Allowing you staff to hire under and reserve team staff is the best time saver feature that's been added.

New mental attribute, 'Negotiation' allowing you to leave a DoF in charge with contractual responsibilities is a personal fav.

New code of conduct feature is another great addition. Automatic fines for various behaviours.

Development centre is a very useful tool.

I have an on going issue with the tactics getting more restrictive though. Have roles, but let us have full control of a position also.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Best version of FM for quite a few years. Didn't bother with FM19 but FM20 is a definite big improvement from FM18. The new development area is a huge plus and I like the Club Vision page which breaks down how well you are performing in your role. Feedback from staff is much better integrated in these new versions and the tactics area is vastly improved.

Match Engine still could do with improvement however and the Press Conferences have barely changed in a decade with the same cookie-cutter responses. That area really needs an overhaul. Overall it's a definite recommend especially if you've been away from the series for a couple of years.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Overall I am a fan of the FM games, as I still seem to pay for them year on year. There are many comments here regarding the price for the game, I think the price is OK, given the depth of the game in terms of content and replayability. A few minor points to pick out for those that have played it over the years. 
Pro's:
- You do feel more in control of your team than in previous years. Through the interactions, youth development, tactics and new staff roles added. Loan Manager = much needed when I get a bit excited with my first big budget. 
- Great lower league experience. I think the game is best played bottom up. Starting with a low level team (I started with Dulwich Hamlet). It can get very same-y if you start with a decent team. 

Cons:
- Promises promises. Some of the mechanisms and potential responses to player promises are lacking. For example, I signed a player and promised to strengthen my team. I did (well I thought I did), I was unbeaten for the season and champions league (up to this point) and the player still complained and wanted to leave. Therefore the player rationale was based on reputation of players, rather than performance of players signed. This happened a few times therefore I stopped promising players anything before I signed them (which meant losing a few). 
- I am not sure if it was just my game, however after being 7-8 seasons in, there was an abundance of world class 17-20 year old strikers coming through. When checking the top scorers of the leagues, they were all created in game and all had ridiculous stats. I would compare it to 8 or 9 Messis coming through at once? WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE CHILDREN 
- Press conferences. Eventually the questions become very, very repetitive and you will always have the same answer for the same question. If you leave it to the Assistant Manager, they tend to go rogue every now and then, therefore perhaps some way to automate, but in line with some preferences would be good.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: There's several issues with this game, a major one is deletion of ALL your player instructions for set pieces if you switch between tactics, the right players will no longer be taking the right positions, the game swaps them all and jumbles them up. Apart from this bug however there are gaping wholes throughout all the game engine, there is essentially no such thing as defending. You can easily conceded a hundred goals a month. The game only recognises attack as a strategy and if you attack correctly you automatically defend, examples including Watford wingbacks on defend against you dribbling past 5 players 90 yards up the pitch cutting inside when they are right footed only and scoring a 30 yard screamer with a long shot rating of 4 and finishing of 6. Expect Raheem Sterling to man mark your players like a good and track back despite pep laying down a high pressing tactic rather than marking. Expect totally phantom tactics regardless of scouting reports such as the opposition defending narrow and man marking when slated for a high line press, you can either press or you can man mark, it also doesn't seem to make any difference what the attributes of the players are the computer can simply play the best tactics against you and their players will fill their roles perfeclty and have perfect squad harmony and passing teamwork no matter having never played that formation against you all season. Whatever you do the entire league will set up specifically to counter just your team including buying players that you need such as inside forwards. The whole game rather than being a challenge seems to be arbitarily cheating against the human player with the entire tactics and game engine and scouting essentially being meaningless, including if you change tactics to spring a surprise the day before the computer will just play with a totally different formation to the one scouted!

review:
Absolute garbage game, very basic programming and gaming engine which goes against everything you want. “Sports Interactive” have a handful of staff, not sure how many programmers, but even in 2020, they cannot produce anywhere close to the AI quality of games such as Halo (Combat Evolved) which is now 15+ years old.
People are commenting on here of how easy they think it is, well, these fall into 3 categories for me.

A)	Liars, just want to promote this game
B)	Addicts with no other games or life, these guys play this game all of their spae time and take it too seriously.
C)	Cheats, these people simply use cheats to win.

If you are like me, a football fan and a casual player of this game, then do NOT waste your money, it is garbage and unless you play a huge team, then you will lose most of your games. It is unrealistic and I have tested this game playing a loss 2-3 times in a row by restarting the game without saving and managed to win most of my games because of their useless programming algorithm, this game promotes the other team more, it wants you to lose. 
Looking at this company in detail, they have made NO progress as a company in over 15+ years which tells me that they have only a loyal fan base and not a large player base like most games. Their lazy attitude of making a quick buck over actually making a very good game and taking pleasure in programming an excellent game just goes to show how naïve their fan base is.

However, somehow the reported major flaws (overpowered long-range strikes, under-powered 1-1 goal scoring) are gone. I actually wonder why since I am not aware of a patch that should have fixed these flaws.
All-in-all, I really love playing this version now. In many ways (more user friendly interface, more information on how things work, more information on setting up tactics, more realistic moves of players in the match engine and curled crosses!) it is better than the 2018 version I used to play.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: The game is worth the price, but you will need an outlet for the inevitable frustration it will cause you. Defenders can't keep themselves between attackers and their goal, attackers can't convert one on one chances, goals fly in from corners and indirect free kicks, players demand new contracts with 3-4 years remaining on their current one, your team will win 5 matches in a row then lose 4 straight, and so on. Frustration is guaranteed because the match engine is wonky and the form effect is too strong. And still, I have to recommend the game because it is addictive and makes you want to keep playing despite its obvious flaws.

review: All i can say ref this game is how disappointed i am, due to isolation i was recommend this game by my brother as a free trail for a week, so i thought why not. Game ran really well on my laptop that is less than a year old, which is use for work every day and also complete all my open university on as well. So when my trial was up i thought why not, so i spent £39.99 on the game. 232hrs later the game has decided not to work or when it does its slow and takes 25 mins to complete 1 game. Ive been online and checked everything i need to ref my system etc making sure everything was up to date. Gave FM20 priority you name i have tried it. Contacted Steam, no good what so ever. Went direct to Sega who told me to try everything i have been doing. To be honest im disappointment in the product and service. The game itself is great and lots of fun and kills time, but the service afterwards is a disgrace and both Steam and Sega should be ashamed of themselves. Biggest waste of £39.99 ever and based on my experience i wouldnt not recommend the game, no for the game itself but for the teams that claim to run/own the game. Worst companies ever and if i was any advertisement or name linked to the game and the game makers i would not want my name linked to it. I can see why Juventus never wanted to be involved. STAY CLEAR

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Football Manager is one of those sporting based franchises which receive a yearly rendition, with what looks like from the outside, nothing more than just a roster refresh. To an extent, that is true with Football Manager, with the database updated for the 2019/2020 football season, a seemingly insignificant change to justify £30 more of your money. However, what Sports Interactive are consistently capable of, is bringing a range of quality of life improvements as well as the occasional larger update that don't necessarily reinvent the wheel, but refine it to it's truest form.
Football Manager 2020 is the best version of Football Manager, hand down, in the same way that Football Manager 2021 will most likely surpass the present iteration of the game. If you are a new player to the franchise, the in game tutorials and menus allow any user to customise and change the many different roles and responsibilities to their liking. Meaning you can slowly ease yourself into the fantastic depth that Football Manger provides for club management. Whilst if you are a returning player, the improvements to aspects like the match engine and the development centre should allow a greater sense of success in the short term while allowing the ability to feel like you have left a legacy with a club in the long term.
Many people may be put off with Football Managers limited licenses in comparison to games like FIFA, with the lack of Premier League licenses, with the exception of Watford, potentially disinteresting a core English audience. Although that being said, the use of the EFL and National League licenses within the game should encourage more lower league management, which in my opinion, provides a much more enjoyable experience than starting your saves at already financially secure and successful teams. Moreover, the complications surrounding the German national team and the Brazilian Leagues can also detract from your experience. However, the ability to install a wide range of graphical and database improvements provided by the fantastic Football Manager community can resolve such issues, these improvements may not be directly supported by Sports Interactive due to legality issues, again surrounding licenses, yet they are perfectly easy to install on the PC version of Football Manager (Simply Google how to install Facepacks, Club Badges, Name Fixes, Entire new divisions, etc).
Football Manager cannot be learnt to play in a day, as much as that may differ certain players, its simply the reality of this game. Football Manager provides a incredible depth to club managements and players will be learning certain mechanics and nuances to the games up to years after playing it. I, myself still learn small things about the game after playing games in the franchise for 4 years now. Yet, If you are willing to brave the seemingly steep learning curve at first glance and learn the core mechanics to this game, I strongly believe you will find yourself hooked into crafting your own narrative and stories through this digital football world.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
As someone who has bought pretty much every year's instalment of Football Manager for the last 10 years running, I have to say this one is a massive disappointment.
The match engine is absolutely abysmal, and simply provides absolutely no reward for creating a good tactic and carving the opposition open as your players will miss one-on-ones and clear cut chances over and over again, irrespective of how good they are supposed to be as a finisher. You will repeatedly find that the game punishes you for playing football, and instead rewards tactics that only focus on Pulis-style hammering of crosses and long balls into the box and set pieces. It is just so horribly demoralising to see your team achieve great stats, dominate possession, shots and clear cut chances, only to watch highlight after highlight of your top strikers repeatedly missing ridiculously simple chances.
I would strongly advice you to avoid this game at all costs and simply play an older version of Football Manager where the engine actually works to reward effective tactics and doesn't leave you pulling your hair out when your key striker, a player who on my save was ridiculously overpowered in terms of his attributes for his level, misses 95% of one-on-ones, spurning 6 clear cut chances only for the opposition to score two headers from corners and win.
Horribly unrewarding, do not play.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The match engine leaves so much to be desired. 

Wide players will attempt to score from the byline several times each game instead of passing to an unmarked striker. 

There are almost no forward passes centrally and no through balls at all, so most goals are the result of a winger, inside forward or overlapping back crossing to the other side of the box where an onrushing winger will score. Or a set piece which seems overpowered to compensate for the relative lack of goals from open play.

Occasionally a midfielder will score a screamer from 30 yards from a cut back but strikers score mostly rebounds and headers from set pieces and get very little service in normal play.

It's very possible to win most your matches by having world-class inside forwards but I finally got fed up with every attack looking the same.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This is a good game, realistic in some aspects but the graphics for the pitch and players are not good - for a game with such price I expected to see the player icons and their models to be accurate but that is discarded here. 

When it comes to tactics, and managing the team it is realistic and even when you are in a match you can edit and adjust accordingly to whoever you are playing against. However, I believe the way players play on the pitch is quite vexing since they do idiotic movements that are not fitting - for an example, your player is right in front of the goal and instead of scoring the goal they decide instead to shoot it at the goal keeper. 

Realism for being a manager and pulling the tactics etc, I give it a 9/10

Player realism on the pitch? 5/10

Graphics and the likes, player icons etc. 3/10

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I have never had much of an issue with fm (gameplay wise) despite a couple bugs and annoying things it has still been fun . However this year i have give up playing it after only a short amount of the. The gameplay is shocking and the developers aren't fixing it. Wingers are constantly shooting at the keeper instead of crossing in the ball or cutting it back. And strikers miss 99/100 chances so you could have 35 shots on target and not a single goal. Considering it is £40 now it is dog shi*e.
I wont be playing it again unless fixes to the game are introduced

Edit: despite a few fixes the gameplay is still very dissapointing and the worst i have seen on a fm game. Each game consists of balls over the top of the oppositions or my defence and the striker scoring every 1 in 7 games or the wing players dribbling past the wing backs and instead of cutting back or crossing the ball in the box they shoot straight at the keeper. Whilst there has been slight improvents the game is still very boring after 5 games. On the other hand leaving out gameplay i am impressed with the other aspects of the game. E.g. transfers , scouting.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Nice new features like the development center, club philosophy etc, together with improvements in general to the game. All these things should improve the already impressive replayability of FM.

HOWEVER, the match engine has disappointed me again. It has similar flaws the FM19 match engine had: strikers are nearly useless, no overlapping runs from central midfield, no through balls attempted, to name a few. Even worse, wingplay has become a joke with wingers and full backs blasting shots at goal from impossible angels. All this after a lot of feedback SI got from the community during FM19 and the FM20 beta.

I hope they can improve the match engine. Until then, this game gets a low score from me and I'll stick to the older FM18.

Update 25 February 2020:
SI has released a big patch earlier this month, also including the transfer updates up until that date. The match engine was changed as well, but this update didn't improve the experience significantly enough to change my initial review of this game.

For future games, I suggest to wait to buy the game until after the winter update as you can then ask for a refund if the game doesn't fulfil your expectations. Now it's impossible to do that because you only get to see the final version of the game 4 months after the initial release.

Update 8 April 2020:
SI have confirmed on the SI community forum they won't release a new update for this game. As such, my negative recommendation will not change.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Usually a huge FM fan and consumer but this years game isn't my favourite, if you've got an older version - stick to that.

Problems with this game: 
Overall - Mainly the matches themselves seem to be utterly unpredictable, completely unmanageable and none of the information stats seems to match up to  to pre-game instructions and player stats.
More specifically.
- Too many 1 vs 1s (missed and created) 
- Too many volleys, header, long shots scored by all players or players with low stats
- Too many goals scored by simply tackling defenders - regardless of press instructions
- The team doesn't really feel like you're managing it. At all levels and situations - making a change in seems to yield rather random results, FM19 seemed to have a better balance of cause and  effect.
- Zebre FC (although i understand why)
-  I think too many chances per game, although i haven't studied the statistics compared to reality
-  seems impossible to 'tighten up' or try and maintain possession. 
-  I'm not overly bothered about match day graphics, as i like 2D Traditional (top down) view. 
- Alot of aimless punts up the pitch/bad computer AI. 
- Teams seem incapable of moving up the pitch as a unit. 
- Lots of stuff appears to happen in the last 10 mins
- Not totally sure all the pre-set style of tactics are necessary.

Anyway - usually a huge fan of this game and left frustrated with this version of it. I see others are having similar issues and  i think these have been acknowledged.

review: Football Manager has been an important part of my life since 2016, the game has come very far and that is reflecting in this year's edition. The in-game mechanics and engine have been improved immensely. The AI now develops better tactics and squad building which punish the player that doesn't critic his tactics and mange his own squad and makes each match even more intense, keeping you on the edge of your seat until the final whistle. Great work by the team over SI and I look forward to playing this franchise for many years to come.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Having played all editions since like 2005, I can say that I finally reached a point where I had enough with this game. It's decent as all the games from the series are, it's undeniable that for all of us football fans there's always a smile to be attained every year when we take our team to the glory and that alone keeps making us play it with a smile everyday. But I think it's time for me to just say, I had enough with buying it for full price and it being exactly the same thing, over, and over, and over again, and guess what, the problems that it always had are still there and I don't think SE will ever fix them.

The game's randomness is it's main problem, it's inconsistent as hell as it's always been and it can become frustrating to a point where you just don't feel like wasting time on it anymore. A good example of this randomness is with injuries, god awful, it doesn't happen in a football team for in less than a month 10 players or more of your team getting injured even when you made sure you have the best physios and conditions in the club. It also doesn't happen your striker with amazing attributes failing 10-20 goals per match, it also seldomly happens that your same striker fails to pass the ball to a colleague that is alone 10 cms on the side and can easily score. Also, players are human beings, and as any conscious human being, you cannot expect a poor team to reinforce your squad with millions when they are not available, but in this game, every single player will create drama for every little thing, and it becomes TERRIBLY annoying at some point. We know now that we live in an era where football players cost a lot of money, but man, after 5-6 seasons, even the lowest of players cost over 5-10 millions and it just becomes impossible for you to deal in any sorts with other teams. Also I doubt that any big team would be able to spend over 600 million every year like I see in this game happening... Another propper example of failure in this game is what happened to me this season, I won a game 4-0 on my first go and I was playing with a team that was inferior to it's adversaries, but not by much, and my PC crashed after. Reloaded the game, and for my surprise I couldn't win that game afterwards anymore for some reason, even though I changed absolutely nothing, now, I normally don't replay games (if I lose I lose, just like in real life, there's always a chance of that happening since everyone has a bad day) but I replayed this game about 10 times and I never won it again. So if that isn't randomness, than what is it? Football doesn't work like that my dudes, of course there's always a chance for any team as long as it's 22 men on the pitch fighting it out, but it puzzles me on how stupid it can be sometimes. I think this algorythm that the game uses, is in no way perfect, but damn, it should've been perfected in 20 years no? It's the least you could do for people that keep cashing in every year.

These same mistakes, of course, arguably, are what set this in being a game and not real life, but when you play a game like this for being a simulation, it should be as accurate to the real thing as it can get, and it puzzles me that in 20 years these dudes have not improved one single bit. 
Now you can come and argue with the "UI has changed, better scouting etc." sure thing, but is it really any way superior year after year? Not really, it is just a different shade of paint on the same painting every year. 

Cannot in any way recommend this game to anyone, even though I have fun with it as I do every year, and as probably I will keep playing it every year, guilty pleasure I guess or the love of football, or maybe both. But it's getting harder and harder to recommend this to anyone, when it's not a football simulator anymore, it's a randomness simulator with football elements.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Unfortunately, for all the excellent aspects of this game - and there are many - the most fundamental part, the match engine, is so disappointing. It is both limited and repetitive; the lack of variation in highlights, goals and overall play is a let down. If you want to rely on set piece goals to win, you're in luck. There are some great aspects - player development, training, transfers, club philosophy, tactical set up - these have been very well implemented. BUT, following all the clicks, drags and efforts to make things the way you want, the match engine takes one giant safety pin to the balloon that is FM's enjoyment.

The ME has never been perfect, or even 'great' in my view, but it has at least in most versions represented your football in such a way you see balance in reward alongside punishment. Not in FM2020 - despite many patches, it is woeful. SI has fluffed it this year. Better hopes for FM2021...

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
As the years go by, I'm finding it harder to enjoy Football Manager. I honestly don't know how this game is any different from FM19. If Sports Interactive were interested in making a good game, they'd release FM once every 2 years and actually take time to improve things. I've been playing since FM12 and even then people were complaining about the match engine. Disappointing that every edition still has a glaring bug when it comes to gameplay (players not squaring the ball, one-on-ones). 

And each new FM seems more focused on feature-creep crap like player interactions and adding unnecessary jobs like data analyst and sports scientist. Why are my players always talking to me when the conversation options feel like they're written by someone who has never spoken to people? Why add data analysts when your scouts keep recommending you Mbappe, Aguero and Varane even though you're managing Norwich? FM is getting more bloated with each year and these features have been gradually eroding away at the actual fun of the series. 

I want to develop unknown youngsters into star players and I want to devise tactics that allow my team to play beautiful football. I don't want to get into an argument with my 18-year-old striker about why I played him as an Advanced Forward instead of a Poacher like I promised. I can understand the realism behind a prima-donna millionaire footballer throwing a  fit but if practically every player in my Vanarama National league team is a ticking time bomb then this game is just nonsensical.

$50 for a transfer update and new ways to piss your players off is daylight robbery.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've played FM since the very first Championship Manager series and have been highly addicted. There have been some high water mark moments and some low points along the way - I've also find it hard to justify spending full game price on a game that for all intents and purposes introduces minor tweaks at best.

I have long lamented the addition of social media and press conferences into the game and managing a world of pre-madonnas isn't exactly my idea of fun but the game has improved greatly in what you can strip out and give to other people to do in-game. Even if they sometimes drop the ball and you have to bail them out!

That said, the game play and quality therein has returned with this iteration - I can honestly say FM20 is going to keep me entertained for a long while yet!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Ruins my life.

Spreadsheets from the Gods.

A Micro-Managers dream.

I rate everything in my life on a scale of 1-20.

"I think there's a lot more to come from you, and I completely believe you've got what it takes"

The feeling of guiding Oldham Athletic to a Champions League Semi Final in 2031, only to be knocked out by eventual winners Djugardens IF on penalties is something that cannot be put into words. Exacerbation, elation at the 67th minute goal to put you in front, heart break at the 87th minute equaliser, stress, delight, devastation, threatened points deductions, transfer embargos.

All whilst sat on your arse whilst Jeff Stelling tells you who's scored Kettering's 4th of the afternoon on Soccer Saturday.

Absolute 10. out of f*****g 10 Jeff. Unbelievable.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: IF you like this game franchise and love football, then this game is perfect fit. This game isn't like the likes of fiffa or pes. Where the new games fixes bugs and player transfers. Here the game knows that players can easily do so the new transfer window matches with the prior game. But in general this game have a much better match system than the prior version, it feels more realistic with movements and positions. The game made it more fun to look at the social media section, with more fan comments on your success or failure as a manager. The game is something you can easily have hundreds of hours with, and is a game that is chill to just sit and simulate while you are dead in LOL or doing some school projects. All in all I recommend this game

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This could be the best FM if the match engine will be fixed. Until then this is mediocre.

Update: 08.03.2020

I waited till the last update. Match Engine kills this game. That's it. You can spend hours with building your roster then coming up with a balanced tactic or whatever. But the match engine is so boring and lightyears from real football that it is too much for me. My centre backs score 10-15 goals from corners and indirect free kicks in one season. My CMs score 7-10 goals / player from outside of the box. In exchange my strikers and inside forwards are retarded in clear cut chances. This is not football.

Update: 20.12.2019

I changed the recommendation to NOT RECOMMENDED. Match engine is still not fixed which is a big problem because it is so unrealistic that I quit playing this game. I am very sad because everything is at least good in the game but the match engine (the main dish) simulates a sport which is clearly not football. 1 on 1 situations (striker against goalkeeper) almost always missed. It's like in a basketball game Lebron James would miss every second dunk... :(

Update: 22.11.2019

Since the last update the match engine favors the AI heavily and it is more broken than before. What I did not experience before:
- 4 out 4 penalties were missed by my pen. taker (fin, pen tak. 16 rating)
- My team shoots 20-30 times on goal (appr. 5-8 long shots) and create 2-5 clear cut chances, meanwhile the AI shoots max 10 per game but scores with 30% (deflected long shots, free kicks, cannon shots from anywhere by Average Joe) . And I have a defensive tactic. I couldn't win 10 games in a row... before the last update I was on a "run" (I am with Real Valladolid in 3rd season and in Europe League, so the "run" is relative definition in this case).
- and in 2 weeks 6 major injuries in the squad...

- I am literally sad that something messed up/made the match engine worse.

What I really don't get is that how can you publish a football simulation which is appr. 20 years old in development and when you start a match and the strikers never score on 1on1s, I can't believe that the developers/testers cannot saw it. I assume SI employees are aware about that strikers tend to score when they are on 1 on 1 against the keeper and not bothered at all by any defender... please someone explain this to me.

See ya after the "real version" is published! I am done with beta testing for my money.

Update: 20.11.2019

compared to fm19 and in just in general:
- less major injuries (more than 3 weeks long), more minor injuries (less than a week), more realistic I think
- match engine is better than fm19 but needs some refining, e.g.:
- 1 on 1 finishing is a joke right now
- long shots overpowered (players with a long shot attr. of 14 are Roberto Carlos Academy graduates)
- wingers/fbs smashing into the sidenet from zero angle instead of crossing
- majestic solos (playing for me Castrovili is Kaka at his best, the AI tends to have a Messi every second match)

The problem is that you can create a team and tactic based on the long shot "feature" and you can kill every team. (possesion game 
+ long shot from anywhere) And it's unreal and boring.

Don't forget to create custom defensive set pieces instructions, AI tends to expose the default settings.

So every part of the game is excellent (can be some bugs of course) except the match engine. Now I would put an "untested/not tested enough" label on the match engine. What I fear is that the 1on1 and the smash into the sidenet things won't be fixed because then every match could be 7-4. The defenders still act time to time like low IQ cows. (they turn around and start running only when the ball is behind them)

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
[B]FOOTBALL MANAGER HAS FINALLY GONE MAINSTREAM IT SEEMS[/B]
Football Manager 2020 is selling like hotcakes, there have been plenty of records broken with the game this year as Miles Jacobsen has been celebrating on Twitter at every opportunity. It's great for the money men, it's great for Sega, but something has changed with Sports Interactive (SI) with this game. The match engine is an abomination this time around and SI have done little to fix it and Neil Brock has basically dismissed the torrent of negative feedback on the official forum saying that SI are happy with with the match engine. He basically said they don't care about the fans that have helped shaped the game series over the past 25-30 years. This is worrying, it is so broken and unbalanced this time around for a senior figure at SI to think this and communicate this with their most diehard fans clearly shows that the drive of improving fundemental features is gone and that the objective it to fluff the game out with nice sounding but useless features to boost the annual marketing push.

I'm so disappointed in this iteration of the series and in my opinion it is the worst Football Manager in many years. The game is jut not fun to play, even with success. There is no way as a Football Manager player of 25 years that I can recommend this game. Football Manager 2021 will be the first game in over 20 years that I do not buy at launch.

New comers to the series you will probably enjoy the game as it will be your first and you will likely be drawn in by the depth and all the things that has made the game great for so many years. But extended play will lay bare the awful match engine which will never be fixed.

[B]NOT RECOMMENDED[/B]

[i]Source: Neil Brock post on official SI forums: https://community.sigames.com/topic/514560-football-manager-2020-january-february-transfer-updates-feedback-thread/?do=findComment&comment=12305407[/i]

[i]Example of issues with the match engine - number of missed one on ones, the number 10 role being useless and bypassed, too many goals from long shots, awful crossing, ineffective central play making all games feel the same, world class strikers scoring paltry amounts of goals, set pieces and long shots being the main source of goals and many many more [B](I suggest looking at the thread linked above to see in depth the fundemental and immersion destroying flaws)[/B][/i]

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The astonishing number of goals from the kickoff. 
The interminable injury time with the inevitable 94th minute winner.
Liverpool and their team of supermen. I paused the game and they had all 10 of their outfield players in my half in open play. I can never get my CB's to go beyond the half way line other than set pieces. I go from from very defensive to very attacking and everything in between. I've replayed the same game 100 times. Can't even get a draw. Law of averages says I should get a least 1 draw surely.
The ability of the AI sides to use pull backs, pass and move. All things my players never do no matter how much I tinker with them. 
I would really like the option of not having to play the match and just let the AI decide the outcome. My suspicion is i would get more wins.
If you want a game that is no fun at all but piles on the frustration this is the game for you. Yet the worst part. It's like a drug. You can't stop playing. Wish I'd never bought the damn game. I really do. Oh maybe try 101 will be the charm.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This is a bit of a mixed review, but I still recommend the game to any FM fan!

For all reasons I still believe that FM18 is still the best title release to date, in my opinion. But, I can't stop playing FM20 for the life of me. Its your standard FM game, but this year your strikers barely score. So being creative with your tactic is more viable to enjoying good results on the field. This is even after the January update!

Should you buy FM20, yes! I give it a solid 9 out of 10! My only gripe with the game itself is the countless problems its had with launch bugs since release. That, and I have it installed on 2 computers.....same specs just different graphics cards. Each install has the same mods on it, yet only my gtx1660ti runs the game. The gtx980 can't even run the game on VANILLA!!!!
Before you ask, yes all the drivers and windows are up to date!
Anyway, back to playing FM20!
