title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I'd start this by ensuring you that I play the game since 1999 and I loved and also hated it ever since, despite the match engine is broken EVER SINCE! I played nearly every iteration in the last 20 years. I just can't understand why nobody could fix the match engine like ever. 

Below I tell you some examples for FM2020:

I play Dortmund right now, but the same thing happens with mostly all the teams I tried to manage...

1. Magic goal at the last second of the game:
Sometimes when the match engine realises that I'm having a better result that (according some hidden rule) I should have, then it corrects itself with a last second goal for the opposing team. It's really last second, so there's no replay, only the match ends and I realise on the scoreline that I lost. (there was also no scoring chance, or passes before, it just happens out of thin air) That bug can really break something deeply inside me...

2. My players are having a bad day:
This issue goes back a long time now, it existed more or less in every iterations of FM. If the RNG generates a bad number for you before the match then you CANNOT win. I've tried to reload the match as long as I got bored (after an hour or so) and every single time I've lost against a much weaker team. (maybe a few draws) I had like 3x the chances yet my players magically forgot how to score. I hit all the posts and crossbar 10 times, the rest goes over or their goalkeeper gets a 8.5 result after saving EVERYTHING. Then the other team goes once inside my box, and they score one from EVERY chance. This is also ridiculous.
2/b: I think that decision before the match is a real thing, as for example competition draws are decided BEFORE the draw. I checked it by saving on the draw day but BEFORE the draw itself. The I reloaded and drew again getting the same exact result over and over again. I getting to belive that matches work about the same. They are decided before, and "simulation" is only eyecandy, but the result (win or loose) is mostly decided before. You can only change in the match how bad it will be...

3. Teams play better with 10 man as with 11:
Also goes back a long time with FM. You are getting a good amount of chances and faring ok in the match maybe even leading by 1-2 goals. Then the opposite team looses a man with red card. After that they magically turn into 10 Messies and beat you up with no chance to counter them. Even if you switch to DEFENSIVE AGAINST A 10 MAN TEAM!! If on theother hand YOU loose a man you are as good as dead, they destroy you...

4. Opposing players magically learn to play football in the middle of the match:
You are getting massive amount of chances and really destroy the opposite team leading by 2-3 goals easily. Then something happens and the opposite team comes back into the game in 10 minutes. If you are lucky you can maybe still win, or draw by the skin of your teeth, but it's often turning into a draw or loss. I've checked, they didn't change tactic or stg. They just learned how to beat me in 10 minutes. 

5. Equalizing from kick-off after goal:
You score a goal, and the opposite team equalises from the kick off after 2 touches. I'm getting this in 2-3 out of 5 games.

Right now this 5 things annony me really after my last couple of matches, but I'm sure I could come up with 5 more if I weren't really pissed off.

All-in-all in this state of match engine you need to be a real fan of the game (like me) to play it, otherwise you will start to hate it for the rest of your life. I still hope that it will somehow be fixed, and I can really play it like it was meant to be, but in it's current state I cannot recommend you to buy and play the game. Wait until it will be fixed (if ever).

Update: Right after writing the report:

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=1938497356

title: Football Manager 2020
review: There are times where this game screws you over. There are times when you want to give up on playing it because the simulation can screw with you to the point where you don't believe that it's possible to be screwed over any more. For example, Barcelona + Pogba + Sancho losing to a team like Mallorca 3-0, while Barcelona gets 2 shots the whole 90min. Then there are times where your team, that you spent hours putting together, actually comes together and plays to expectations. That's what's so satisfying about this game. Building a team of young stars and old ones that can compete against the best teams and come out victorious. Overall, for this game to enjoyable you have to actually spend some time building up a team, meaning multiple seasons not just one. If you think you can spend time on a single game for hours at a time, and you enjoy building a football team into your own vision, then you should definitely give this a try. Even if you choose to refund it at 2hrs.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Off and on I have been a player of Football Manager and before that Championship Manager for a number of years, this is the first time for a while I have decided to return to the full version of the game rather than the touch version.
I have really tried to like this game but it only really ever serves to frustrate, most of the problems with this game I feel revolve around the match engine. I cannot even begin to estimate how many times I have dominated games in possession, shots & shots on target yet suffered defeat. On a very frequent basis I see my team generating well over twenty shots and over ten on target yet lose the game to a team generating only 2 or 3 shots. I recall this being a football manager curse over many seasons and hasn't been addressed, it simply isn't realistic and to say it happens in 2 out of every 3 games I play really wouldn't be an exaggeration. I accept it may happen from time to time but it is happening in virtually every game I play.
Method of goals being conceded is also dull, repetitive and unrealistic. I would estimate that 90% of the goals I concede are from balls lumped over the top to the striker who scores one on one with the keeper, I have tried lots of different instructions & formations to my defence but to no avail. This may be less frustrating if my strikers didn't miss 90% of their one on ones. But again, wholly unrealistic.
Their are other frustrating aspects to the game, particularly 16/17yr old prospects demanding moves to a bigger club before they are even good enough to break into the reserves never mind the first team. Undeterred they also demand promises of first team football in contract negotiations regardless of their talent, they just can't be reasoned with.
Media interaction seems to have changed little and the same boring, repetitive, pointless unrealistic questions crop up without an option to say anything even remotely like what you would like to say in response. Of course you can you send your assistant to say all the wrong things if you prefer. Surely this could be more imaginative.
I don't want the game to be easy, I want it to be fair. The vast majority of the games I play leave with me with the feeling of having been cheated, it's almost as if the game wants you to lose.
The most damning verdict I can give of any game is that is simply isn't fun and sadly this version of football manager not only isn't fun, it's a chore.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Heres the reality of what I had seen so far on the game and this beta release:
The match engine so far is a ABSOLUTE DISGRACE.The main thing about it is players don't adhere to certain tactical instructions at all. They simply don't adhere to instructions like : pass it shorter , shoot less often etc. Players love launching the ball for absolutely no reasons. Centerbacks launch the ball forward to a striker. Play constantly "switches" to other flanks about 3495895 times a game. Players loose possesion for no reason without even any pressure on them. Players miss 1v1 chances that are easier to score than miss on a CONSISTENT basis and dont get me wrong when i tested on my test juve save i won league 102 pts and all cups and cl semi  but i had seen this from TOP strikers like higuain etc miss TIME AND TIME AGAIN 1v1 chances however what DOES go in is : long shots , indirect free kicks , free kicks from rediculous ranges etc. The football being played is just rediculous. Often times players can't string a pass when they have obvious passing options they still launch a ball even with individual instructions such as shorter passing ( and i tested with good players.) 

NOW AS FAR AS GAME IN GENERAL AND NEW FEATURES:
The most notable feature in the game is that the board intervenes now when u dont follow certian philosophies such as sing players under 23 for first team etc. They might cancel future transfers u make because u didnt sign or adhere to these philosophies.

Theres also now a "code of conduct" that automatically disciplines players for various offenses such as missed training , red card etc.

And thats about all I saw so far new.
The game is roughly the same as last year except now the match engine in the beta at least is piss poor and needs RADICAL changes for the game to be worth playing.

HERES A UPDATE:
WHEN THE FUCKING PATCH 20.2 CAME OUT IT ABSOLUTELY PUT A NAIL IN THE COFFIN OF THIS FUCKING MATCH ENGINE. THE GAME UPON FULL RELEASE BECAME PLAYABLE FOR  A BRIEF PERIOD OF TIME BUT THEN THEY FUCKING KILLED IT WITH THE 20,2 PATCH. YOU CAN SEE ON FMARENA WHAT IT DID TO TOP TACTICS AND BELIEVE U ME IF TOP TACTITIANS LIKE KNAPP CANT CREATE A WORTHWHILE TACTIC ON THIS VOMIT NEITHER CAN YOU.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
So after some time and some updates, some insight and experience, i have decided to rewrite my review.
So the game as it are are still bugged, they did sort some of the more paramount things out and iam both a fan and not a fan of their match engine at the same time, i can see a lot of good things in it, but also some annoying bugs, i have more faith now than at last review, that those bugs will be sorted out.
iam currently really enjoying my game, specially after i found out how to counter to poor goal conversion rate with tactic and traits(not using exploit tactics) just took me some time to really build a decent tactic tailored for my players, the thing i hated most was poor 1vs1, its still poor but you can counter this with some traits on your attackers. also the fact that my wingers kept shooting into the side of the net instead of trying to pass it, sorted that out too with shoot less + the trait "looking to pass rather than score"
ofc this takes time to train, unlesss your using editor, i do prefer the normal way myself, even tho i own the editor. they fixed the stats bug that rendered most of the regens useless, so now one can enjoy newly created wonderkids again. so with this in mind i decided to change my negative review, to a positive.
my old review is readable below this new one.


Old Review: 
"this game have been one of my favorite games for almost 10 years, and i can say that if this is the way they expect to continue, i am done. the match engine is a mess and there are a lot of weird stuff happening in matches, some matches seems to be predetermined, so no matter how many times you reload and change tactics and players you cant get a different result, new regens are generated without all their stats set, so all their undefined stats end up as a 1, which makes them useless, so long games arent a posiblilty at the moment, there are a lot of fixing before i would recommend anyone to use money on this game, so save your self some headache and stick with the 2019 version until they have fixed this game, who have to potential to be the best FM ever, but at the moment are unplayable unless your someone who edits everything."

review:
STILL AMAZING BUT HAS ITS ISSUES. THE 3D MATCH GRAPHICS ARE STILL AWFUL. KEEPERS ALWAYS MAKE MISTAKES. THE BREXIT PART OF THE GAME LEFT ME WITH 2 LOAN PLAYERS I HAD FOR THE SEASON UNABLE TO PLAY FOR ME BECAUSE THEY COULDNT GET A WP. PLAYERS GOING FOR FREE TO OTHER CLUBS BUT THEY WANT 50M FROM MY CLUB. THE FACT THAT THERE IS NO POINT IN NEGOTIATING LOAN TEEMS BECAUSE THE CLUBS ARE SO RIGID. YOU CANT GET CLUBS TO PAY A WAGE PERCENTAGE OR DROP THEIR LOAN FEE EVEN IF THE PLAYER IS GOING TO ROT IN THE RESERVES. COACHES RETIRING YOUNG BECAUSE THEY CANT GET A JOB BUT THEY WONT ACCPET BIG OFFERS FROM YOU. NOT BEING ABLE TO EVEN TALK TO PLAYERS THAT ARENT INTERESTED IN JOINING YOU TO TRY AND PERSUADE THEM. THE PRESS CONFERENCES ARE A JOKE AND IF YOU PLAY 5 SEASONS, GETS MONOTONOUS BEING ASKED THE SAME QUESTIONS. THE SAME REPLIES ALWAYS.....PLAYERS MOANING ABOUT THINGS AND THE LACK OF RESPONSES. HOW OFTEN DO YOU HEAR A PLAYER COMING OUT AND MOANING ABOUT NOT PLAYING WHEN HE IS IN THE SAME POSITION AS THE BEST PLAYER AND YOU ARE TOP OF THE LEAGUE.PLAYERS SIGNING NEW CONTRACTS AT THE END OF THE SEASON AND THEN ASKING FOR A NEW ONE AS SOON AS THE SEASON STARTS AND ROCKING THE BOAT IS ANNOYING. YOU WANT TO BE REALISTIC AND SOME OF THIS IS PONY. LAST ONE. FINDING A PLAYER AT A PONY CLUB WHO HAS A VALUE OF 10K ASKING FOR 50M PLUS 50% OF THE PROFIT OF THE NEXT FEE, THEN SELLING HIM 2 WEEKS LATER TO SOMEONE ELSE FOR 10K.

SOUNDS LIKE I DONT LIKE IT, I PROMISE I DO, THESE THINGS ARE JUST AN ANNOYING FEW POINTS FROM AN OTHERWISE GREAT GAME. I DONT STOP PLAYIG IT.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
In my opinion this is the best iteration of FM I have played. However there are still negatives with it though as with every game.

Positives:
The new development centre allows for players like me who like using younger players and youth prospects to use there own intake more often.
The game is much better (in my opinion) at predicting and producing realistic results whilst also providing upsets such as in my personal Ipswich career gave me an fa cup win over Everton but a league thrashing by a newly relegated Southampton.

Negatives:
I do think that the way you find and approach free agents could do with an improvement as you should have a level of knowledge about their ability as well as be able to search for them specifically as a separate section instead of a broad transfers section.
I also think the way that interviews for prospective jobs need to be altered as on many occasions a chairman will question me about things that haven't happened to me such as media controversy.

Overall I really do enjoy this game and I will probably play it for a long time yet. Or at least until the next one comes out.

title: Football Manager 2020

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Post Update Edit: Players now pass it into the box more often now when they have an option instead of shooting. Sometimes they do in fact shoot it from a narrow angle , but it's rather seldom. The 1v1s are still treacherous though. No improvement whatsoever.

I genuinely mean this when I say it, FM20 has, without a doubt, the worst match engine SI has ever implemented. The most common complaint this game has received so far is that strikers consistently miss 1v1s. Unfortunately this problem is rampant in this game. While this has been a problem in previous FMs, I can comfortably say I have yet to see a striker score from a 1 on 1 situation in my first 12 hours of gameplay.

 Not. A. Single. One.

What's this? My winger received an excellent through ball into the box? Oh that's great, if he strikes the ball he might sco-- why is he running all the way to the end of the pitch? Now the angle is far too narrow to get off a decent shot. Well at least he's in an excellent position to lay it off it in to my striker who's wide ope- oh he shot it at the keeper anyways.

You will see this happen every game, multiple times. It will consume your highlight reel. It's completely unrealistic. Drives you mad especially when you're losing because your opponent has had one shot from long range at your keeper, and your keeper is a brain dead nonce who dives over the ball. 

Overlapping full backs are an absolute nightmare. Even worse than wingers. They get themselves in great crossing positions, but consistently decide to get closer to the keeper, but engage them at a narrow angle. Always. Sometimes they even shoot with their weaker foot.

JUST PASS THE CUNTING BALL MATE.



Fuck this shit. I'm going back to FM 13.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
game is disgustingly bad, have made no attempt to fix any of the beta problems crosses are crap, 1 on 1s are broken and shooting is ridiculously overpowered from outside the box while being completely nerfed inside with fullbacks/strikers constantly shooting from 4 yards away either straight at the keeper or into the side netting. SI could at least pretend they care about the community and produce a working match engine before release day these have all been problems since day 1 of the beta. And before i get the usual "ITS YOUR TACTICS!!!" "what player roles/instructions do you use" "ive won the champions league with accrington stanley" I honestly dont care, regardless of what roles/instructions/tactics someone is ysing theres no excuse for creating ten 1 on 1s a game and not scoring any of them. Games just garbage at the minute and really needs sorted, even games you win arent fun anymore.

*mostly sorted the match enginenow if it would stop crashing every 10 minutes would be fine :) *

title: Football Manager 2020
review: The past 5 seasons or so of FM has been made unfairly difficult for human players by not allowing our players to score goals despite bossing shots on goal, shots on target stats etc. How many times do my players need to miss free headers and one on ones whereas opponents can score the most outrageous goals from their own half to clinch the game? How many times do I need to hit the woodwork 3 times or more? You go look at Piatek's finishing and penalty attributes but he only scores 5 or less goals a season as a regular starter and missed all 4 of his penalties in regular time until i hooked him off penalty duties forever! It is no use creating the best tactics and get your team to shoot from close range and get plenty of shots at goal when the FM creators want you to miss it. I've missed the last FM cos of this, and i am totally regretting giving this a shot. The 3D match engine is a horror as usual but it is not even the biggest bugbear. I know there aren't a decent alternative out there but come on FM fanboys, please critique this game fairly. It is crap. Period.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Been playing this for 5 or 6 years. I enjoyed the 2019 version enormously, and I'm only in the foothills of coming to grips with the 2020 offering, so everything that follows is provisional. But it looks hugely promising. More things you can work with which gets you even deeper into the game. The ways you can manage the tactical setup of the team are better and the game engine seems to have changed.
There seems to have been a step backward, though, in that player AI seems to have failed to get forwards to stay onside again. This was a pain in the backside in previous issues, but was far better in 2019. Seems to have got lost again in the new version, leading to unrealistic numbers of offside calls.
Also one disappointment. You can only specify the first ball in set plays - so you have the corner to the near post, but you cannot then specify, for instance, that the man at the near post heads down for an onrushing player.. The management of set plays has been static for some time and I would dearly like it to expand for corners and free kicks and also to offer moves you can set up in open play. Understand it might be technically complicated, but- for me at least - it would open a whole new dimension.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Tl;Dr 3/10 at best. Get it on sale if you have too. Personally wont be buying future versions of the game until below issues are addressed. 

This game is basically just a database update on FM19. Sure they added some small, new features like the "development center" and detailed contract negotiations but don't let that layer of gloss fool you. The "bread & butter" aka the match engine and tactical aspects of the game are completely crap.  Also, graphics are still very poor compared to other smaller budget games of the same genre.

Some examples:

- Fullbacks and wide players won't make obvious passes or crosses in the final third. Half of your highlights will be this.....over and over and over again.....especially infuriating when you're behind. 
- Your tactical instructions will be completely ignored. Ex: Set an instruction for your center-mid with superb stats for "teamwork" to "shoot less"? Screw that. He'll shoot from odd angles and distances anyways. Icing on the cake is that, more often than not, he'll often even score.
- Forwards are even worse. Clear-cut chances that even your grandma wouldn't miss, go begging. This will be the other half of your highlights for most games. 
- Through balls and passing is still kinda unrealistic and wonky. Most through balls don't...well..go through. While passing is just silly from time to time with players constantly switching the ball to the opposite flanks as if everyone is Paul Scholes or Pirlo. 

Side criticisms of the game:

- $50 dollars and they don't even have critical licenses, kits or logos like for Juve.
- Graphics are still very outdated compared to much lower budget games of the same genre.
- Weird lag, glitches and bugs can be found from time to time. Ex: blank screen appearing rather than the pitch during 3D matches when using custom skins. 
- Game feels too script-y. I don't know how to explain this but I just don't "feel" like I am playing the game anymore. Everything feels scripted like there's coded scenarios or animations for every possible input I make tactically. I hope I make sense. Maybe add more scripts so the game at least feels rich and realistic, idk?

Overall I definitely won't be purchasing any future versions of the game after being a FM fan for over a decade with thousands of hours of game time.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This game is VERY similar to FM19, that's not a bad thing, its just they've not even bothered to change the UI interface this time so that it feels new even when its really not.

It is what it is, £35 to get a brand new updated and comprehensive database, slight polish of engine and management functions.  

There seems to be a very consistent theme of pre-determined bad results, your wingers will always shoot from stupid tight angles, the opposition will always have a one in two, maybe three shot conversion rate, yours will be one in twenty-five, every top player for you will consistently underperform across all tactics/formations.  The engine seems a bit broken and its not fun to play!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Due to sub-par Match Engine the game ceased to be as realistic as it used to be. It is incredibly and painfully frustrating to witness:

- the strikers missing so many 1-on-1 chances (despite decent attributes)
- wingers/wing-backs shooting the ball into the side netting rather than crossing (despite instructions)
- players missing more penalties than they score (again despite decent attributes)

At least one of the above happens 2-3 times per game. At first, when you are excited with the new features, you ignore it and focus on the good stuff. But when you are 80 hours into the game - honestly there is nothing much you can draw your attention to. To sum up, the game is enjoyable, but is a step back in the series and is totally not worth its price. It is beyond my understanding how did the devs not spot these issues during testing.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Its almost unplayable and feels more like FIFA - scripted, stupid and not reminding of football at all. I had high hopes for this one, but there are only superficial additions which are almost useless or well past due date, while match engine (including 3D) is on almost comical level. Number of missed one on ones goes into hundreds during the season - you will simply stop caring if your player is clean through or in good chance, because he won't finish 9/10 chances. 

Even players with 20 teamwork are not able to square pass into better position for tap in, everyone is attempting shots from 90 degree angle. Sweeper keepers are watching people round them in small box. 

UX is horrible, interactions largely same as past 5 years and negotiations simply unengaging, probably unfinished. I long for a days, when Football Manager was so advanced, you could actually set up your team formation for defensive and offensive phase.   

Its great thats game sells more units every year, but it has probably more to do with marketing. Like the SI guys, but this title is simply so weak, it really starts to remind me of whole FIFA cycle.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
UPDATE--played another 84 hours. 

I feel like this game is much more scripted than past games. I played as Arsenal and am 2nd in the EPL now. FA Cup comes around, and I have tried, I kid you not, 11 times to beat a League 2 team. Every single time, a different player gets a red card and I lose by at least one goal. I still lose even if I try to take a vacation and sim. 

This is about par for the course too. I've had Lewandowski line up next to Laca, and watch him receive a pass two meters in from the penalty spot, but hit the shot so poorly that it goes out for a THROW IN. That's nearly impossible. I convert 1 on 1 opportunities at maybe a 10-15% rate, and I had 37 shots on target against Ipswich Town but lost 2-1 because their keeper had over 30 saves. Something is really broken in the mechanics around shooting (and making the easy pass on a 2 on 1 instead of shooting it into the side netting) that makes the games within the game unplayable until fixed.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

I rarely leave reviews, but I feel like it's important to for this game. I've played these games since Championship Manager 2004 I believe, so I've spent thousands of hours (yikes) not just on Steam.

First of all, the match engine is broken. Shattered. Useless.

I've had more games than I can count with over 25 shots on target and haven't scored a goal, I've tried every tactic in the world to try to get touches to my Trequartista but can't get the ball to him, I score the majority of my goals from outside of the box even tho I almost always use "Work Ball into the Box" (I try to mainly play an Arsenal Tiki Taka), but most frustratingly of all are 1v1s.

1v1s are pointless. I've scored exactly one in more than a whole season of play, regardless if the finishing is 12 or 19--mind you, a lot of these goalies were **** from Sky Bet Championship in cup play too. I've yet to see them make an extra pass inside the box to score a goalie (again, think Arsenal) even when I've had a 4 to 1 break (he shot it from outside the box). It's unbelievable how hard it is to score a normal close goal. Want to win? Figure out a solid defensive structure, counter, and fire away from 30m because you're better off with that than 2 forwards and an AMC against a goalie. 

The UI is solid and the visuals are fine, nothing too exciting, but the board is ruthless. I signed Vignato who scored 18 goals and 15 assists in his first season, and was considered a decent price, but I still got a B on the signing. No explanation why. 

In all honesty, if I hadn't pre-ordered, I would ask for my money back on this game and wait until next year. I'd just get an updated roster for FM 2017, which I think has the most balanced match engine of all the recent games, because I want to try to emulate football management, and this game resembles very little the game I love.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Another year another football manager game. 
Don't get me wrong it's a good game, but still has it's issues like every FM has (and probably will), this one to me seems a little more perfected but it doesn't stop some down right perplexing things happening during matches. 
There are a few nice additions this time around, like the development centre so you can focus on youth growth. More staff positions add a realistic feel and give you more options to delegate tasks to. Club vision now allows you to make a five year plan with your board adding to the overall feel of being the manager of a club. 

Is it better than FM 19, to me yes. 
Is it a radical change that makes you "feel wow...this is so new..." no it is not. 
It's a game for long term fans of the series but is a great entry point for new players, it feels very accessible and there are plenty of websites out there to give help with guides and tactics. I find the UI is easy to navigate and easy to find what you're looking for.

I'm hoping to see some issues addressed in future patches but that of course remains to be seen. 
Eg. Youth players demanding ridiculous wages, penalty conversions I have had an issue with though it's been better since the last patch.
There are more that many others I am sure have mentioned so I won't bother with a long boring list to read through. 

Solid 8/10
If you go for it I hope you enjoy it too!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Try the demo first to see if it's for you.

Been playing since the beta opened and been having a great time, here's some of my key takeaways to help anyone considering buying:

Streamlining:
The game at this point can essentially play itself with you in charge, I never touched some features in previous versions and never really wanted to. Now you can take charge of exactly as many duties as you want and the game feels so much smoother and more fun and you have the peace of mind knowing every aspect of your club is being used reasonably effectively. Obviously you get best results by reading guides online and implementing it yourself but to save you time and stress this feature is really useful

Man Management:
In FM19, regardless of my Discipline stat, players were kicking down my door every 5 minutes to whine about something. I'm happy to report they've reigned this in significantly for FM20, yes you still get issues but they seem to be more grounded in what is actually happening.

Feedback:
SI have really revamped the amount and quality of feedback you receive so it's now much more clear what you are doing that's working and what you need to change on a variety of fronts

In game:
Other criticisms you're seeing are right, you don't score many one-on-ones regardless of quality and pressing seems to lead to high number of bookings, but it's the first version of FM where I'm clearly seeing the tactics I'm selecting actually playing out, YMMV. Seem to score from range a lot more consistently though, so it's swings and roundabouts.

It's worth checking out if you're looking for a experience that CAN be less intimidating and slow, but allows veterans to delve into all the minutiae of this very deep management sim.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: Not sure why this game has positive reviews . Either people at Si are posting there own reviews or people are blind im not sure . This game should be renamed Crash Football because the Si Forum is littered with people complaining about the game crashing or not loading . This is typical of Si every year the game is released in an unfinished format and then you have to rely on Fixes and updates . Always one before Xmas then one after and if your lucky another one in March and then its on to the next years game . By the time you get to play it its due for a new release . I have counted 10,000 posts in there bug section on there forum at this time and the game has only been out 3 weeks . There is no competition for this franchise and they treat there public with discontent every year . You cant even complain on there forum as you get banned . Poor Match Engine coupled with poor graphics make this laughable but the interface is good before it crashes . Jittery graphics which has plagued this game since 2018 has still not been fixed . Lots of potential in this game is let down by a poor company with budgets and time restraints . Strangely enough FM17 is a far better game . As a score for a review having played Football Manager since FM2008 i would give it a 45 / 100 not the 85s or 90s that the payed reviews from game sites give  . Download the demo and try for yourself though as this is just my thoughts

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The improvements are good in my eyes but the game mechanic turns real bad this year. Players act mostly weird.

Some things i noticed

- My goalkeeper did this several times, a ball is shot low and my goalkeeper makes a high dive
- Players pass the ball and for some reason they dont pay attention anymore to the game, like he pass and someone pass back and he just walk a different direction,
- Players sometimes dont even look at the ball when defending but walking around
- in a sprint in defence, the player suddenly stop IMMIDIATLY for no reason.
- sometimes they just walk to a ball and the opponent sprint from 20 meter and gets the ball
- The players make 3-4x weird moves when tackled in one position (Gets tackled) but still manage to keep the ball.
- saw some players get tackled and no one is near the person.

one thing improved in mechanic: The old FM when a goalkeeper stops the shot and the ball goes to the line, your own player gets the ball but stand there as a idiot and the defender steals the ball behind from him, this happend many times but i did not see it in this version.

shortly gameplay is improved but the game mechanic is worse then ever.
- sometimes a player is behind a other player but makes a iceskating move and he get in front of the other player

Really i think i will go back to FM19 the game mechanic killing me now. If you like to be anoyed and break your screen then play this game. This is probaly my last fm if the game mechanic will be like this.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Understandably, as someone who has clocked up roughly 8,500 hours playing the FM series thus far from CM00/01 to the current iteration, I'd like to think I know what makes a good Football Manager game and what has historically let the series down. FM20 does the best job of any instalment so far of improving and expanding on the good and dealing with the negatives.

The match engine is fantastic. Players move in a convincing way; stepovers, Cruyff turns, stop-and-go, all represented here in the best match engine to date. Yes the crowd animations are repetitive but you know what, if you want to play FIFA, go and play FIFA.

The IMMENSE scale of the game means you might feel overwhelmed by your responsibilities and the sheer amount of clicking you need to do to establish your latest season but please, friend, worry not! Along with all these new options comes a wealth of new staff responsibilities, and you can delegate or take charge at your leisure, Like to finalise signings but don't really care about the scouting side of things? Delegate it. Prefer to find those hidden gems yourself but couldn't care less about negotiating their contracts? Sure, delegate it. Want to keep an eye on your blossoming U23 side but the U18s are just too far off your radar right now? Guess what? Delegate it.

I haven't been this impressed with the advances in a Football Manager title since FM13, everything you can think of that would improve the series from FM19 is here. Data presentation is fantastic, player development and progression is as close to perfection as it could be. FM20 makes the complicated things seem simple and makes the simple things seem effortless. To me, this is now THE Football Manager title. 

Simply put, FM20 is a defining moment in the history of Football Manager titles. Make no mistake, this one is a classic. Though you may not find the next Tonton Zola Mokouko sitting in Derby County's reserves, every story you do write for yourself on this genre-defining game will carry its own memories and legacy and surely that is the highest praise of all.

Ps. Match engine is still sometimes a bit of a joke

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I do not get it why so many people give a good review. It is basically the same game as last year with mini changes. So it cost 55 euros for a game that has no minor changes to last year. 

What makes me really want to scream at this year FM are two things besides of the broken match engine:

1. not good looking graphics - do you actually have a art director or somebody with a good esthetic feel? The 3d Graphic are not appealing at all. It is as you are playing a game from 2005 or worse. Stadium looking all the same. Even if you do not have the licens just do a bit on an afford to build stadium which maybe looking nearly the same es the originals. The light in 3d mode is off - it is not a very good atmosphere. And the most funny part is the weird looking black dots on the grass to simulate that the usage of the pitch. I really do not get this at all.

2. animation of the players are - how do i say it - weird. Player sliding over the pitch or moving strange. They do not behave as they should in a 2019 engine. 

But overall it is the best football manager right now - it is actually the only one or i would say there is no competition. So maybe this is why it feels as you playing the 2019 version with half assed changes.

You have a big publisher on hand and i am not sure why it is like this. It feels like that the match engine got dummer. If you watch the whole game you can see that something feels of. Just read the forums. I guess many people are not happy with it.

I just do not want to buy a database every year. I want also good graphics and a good engine. Please get somebody for your team that can make it happen.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Yes it's BETA, but it's poor. Not really a lot can be wrong with the skin etc. so it mostly comes down to the ME - and it is shoddy. 

Every Ai attack is a simple punt over the top for the striker to chase - regardless of how deep you defensive line is, how little you press, how tight the marking is (or not). Makes no difference - punt finds the striker/winger/full back in acres of space.

Another issue is how many times per game you hit the post. 5? 6? Not an uncommon number.

Full backs refuse to cross - despite their instructions to do so "...more frequently".

Your players rarely win headers.

The old "stand there swinging left and right until I'm tackled even though I have an easy pass on" is still there.

SI have had several years to sort out these problems in the ME and each time, the same problems. Makes you wonder exactly what they can justify the £35 for - except for a new purple skin of course.

Edit. Can't help but also notice how the percentage of injuries have increased since release - and the release of the in-game editor. 

Furthermore, the Ai will arbitrarily give you a "bad run of form" once a season - without fail. Just now, I played around with a game v. Atalanta in the Serie A. Played the game three times and all three resulted in a 0-0 draw despite Atalanta registering 0 shots in the three games. My team registered between 5 and 12 shots on target. As a test, I reloaded and went on holiday giving my assistant instructions to use the same team and instructions I had used in the previous 3 attempts. With the Assistant manager in charge using my tactics and team selection the three results came in as 1-3, 2-3 and 0-3 in my favour. Why would the three results be so different despite using my instructions and team selection when the only difference is that the Ai is in charge on the team?

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
it's smoother game than before, faster loads, etc. a little more variation in match engine than fm 19. more depth info and management side. i was skeptical, but it's the best FM yet.
cons:
- i needed to adjust to the bright/strong colors. i preferred smoother color. since i'll play this game for hundreds if not thousand of hours, smoother colors will definitely appreciated. like "matte" colors.
- team selection view by default with team shape minimized and positioned at the bottom left, i find it very annoying when i dragged a player to a certain position and the formation getting blocked by attributes comparison pop-up.
- sometimes achievement not show up right away. i got "Total Support" and "Superb Dressing Room Atmosphere" a little while after i actually getting it on the game. maybe it's good that the records not lost. maybe finally i'll get Goal of the Month achievement that has been bugged a few years before.
- there are a few bugs here and there, but i expect it will be patched. for example:
-- often when i make substitution and tactical tweaks, then i clicked confirm, there was no option to give team talk so then there is no option to confirm changes. it stuck and i have to start over. there are 2 button, confirm and team talk. i always want to give team talk but maybe i clicked wrong (confirm) so this bug appear. but still, fix this, or erase confirm button so it's automatically give team talk.
-- when i confirm substitution/s, and before it happens, my player on the pitch got a red card. it gets messy.
-- sometime after a game, i can't go into dressing room. just next to inbox, annoying.
-- there are more but i forgot, but mostly about match day and team selection. other then that, improvements on managerial, development and training is satisfying.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
So I have played over 1600 hours in FM 18 and over 1300 hours in FM 19 and I can say that in the 48 hours I've played FM 20, I've enjoyed it. The development center is a nice upgrade to get a quick snapshot view of promising youth players. The in-game engine seems better (I tend to play with better teams so maybe the difference is more notable there) and players' touches and passes seem to look and feel better.

With the good, there is of course the not-so-good.

1) Bugs. In the staff tab, when I click on "youth team staff"(u-19 or reserves), sometimes the click does not work. It just sits there. This also happens vice-versa when i am in the u-19 staff menu and i click on "first team staff" and of course again it doesnt work. In game, there is also issues again with inside forwards/wingers just running down line and shooting it straight at the near post. It seems like you need to have 15 vision, passing, teamwork, and the "pass before shoot trait" in order to get your player to actually just simply cross the ball to your open forward. Speaking of forwards, for the last 3 years pure single-striker systems struggle to have a consistent scoring striker. Maybe its just the formations I play (vertical tiki-taka for the most part) but I find it hard sometimes to get my striker to consistently score. 

2) Ridiculous training injuries. Why the hell do some of my players randomly get a "Training injury" all the time. Also, one thing I've noticed, if you haven't saved in a while, the game will throw an injury your way. IT HAPPENS ALL THE TIME. I personally dislike injuries very much, but that is my preference.

All in all, the game is absolutely worth getting for the FM fans and newcomer. The game does a great job in helping you progress through a campaign and set you up for the future with the new development system. I will be curious to see how they fix some of the bugs and issues in the game but once they do, the game will be perfect.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Is this an improvement on fm19? Yes. Is it worth it at full price? Depends.

For me, yes. I play each game for hundreds of hours and make databases and the like. The development centre is a big plus for me, as it focuses on one of the best aspects of the game - developing wonderkids. The quality of life updates all over the shop are brilliant to have as well - you really notice the difference.

The thing that makes me positive that it was a good decision is that I could never go back to FM19 now, I really like the new features and playing without them would just feel inferior now. Make of that what you will.

As to the match engine, in the beta there certainly were many missed one on ones, and wingers shooting from ridiculous angles. Happily I can see that I do not experience these issues any more than I did in previous iterations of the game now. I wouldn't say the match engine is an improvement but after the updates it certainly isn't a step back anymore.

Overall, if you're gonna play this game for over 100 hours, buy it. If not, save your money, or wait for a sale. It's another solid iteration which certainly makes some improvements, but isn't improving any faster than in previous years.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: I've been playing FM since 2011, and i enjoyed most of them. I have to admit this version i do not like. Mostly because of the match experience, it is very frustrating.  I am just a few matches away from selecting to see only the goals.  Every match ( without exceptions) my players miss at least 5-6 times one-on-one. This happens for the openent as well. There have been this kind of misses in the previous versions (which is normal, strikers miss one on ones sometimes) , but the percentage in this one is way too high. I also see a lot of errors with the off-side rule, and also a lot of weak back passes - from my midfield directly to the opposing striker. Again, way to often this things happen.  I think the match experience requires major upgrade.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
So there are some good new features this year BUT... that doesn't matter really because the game is broken.

The match engine is dire this year. DIRE.  Frame rate loss and stuttering are terrible problems, and the actions of the players are just ridiculous. Players dribble for 50 yards down the pitch on a regular basis without any attempt from another player to challenge them.  You don't really feel like your decisions and tactical tweaks make much of a difference to the action either. 

Additionally the text bar commentary is STILL semi disconnected to what you actually see happening on the pitch.  
Example :  The text will say something like " Wow, that assist was just delightful!!"  when it was a boring and totally normal short pass that a 12 year old could make.

A LOT of work and patching needs to be done to make this game worth buying.  Most of it centres around the poor match day simulation. Wait till they at least try and fix it..... and don't buy for now.

review: A lot more information displayed. Grades for fan reactions AND board assessments. Graphics are improved but still need some fine tuning. Hopefully you enjoy it as i have so far.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
They've completely sucked the enjoyment out of playing the game!

Where do I start?

First of all I was loving the original Beta I took Leeds in the 1st season up as champions, finished 14th EPL in the 2nd and in the 3rd season my crowning glory 4th and a cup final.

I thoroughly enjoyed meeting the fans and boards objectives scouting the world to find the best bargain next world class stars, picking up wonderkids and developing the quality players that were already there. Loved the attacking football and watching my goal machines do their thing,

Where did it go wrong you ask?

As soon as SI started fiddling around and patching things! Now granted the game was released with a lot of cosmetic bugs things like not being able to delete notes and fine players etc however game play was fantastic I would count myself as the majority who just want to sign scout and train players and get on with things and do well with the odd challenge and let things develop season on season as better players come in,

However now that they have patched the game it has become so bloody boring, my team which is full of world class players and stars in the making now barely beat the weak teams by a goal and are losing and drawing against teams they should annihilate even lost 4-1 when I was drawing 1-1 after THEY got a player sent off. Also had several games where there have been 7 bookings in a game and sending's off between both teams and I am not even set to 'get stuck in'

Anyhow the tactical familarity of my team is great the morale is great squad is incredibly talented I have 3 different tactics to choose from some tweaked and newer than others because as we all know the AI learns your tactics after 8/10 games.

I am someone who has been playing these games probably for the best part of 25 years so i know my stuff but because of poor decisions on SI's part the game play and match engine is both boring and unresponsive.

I was hoping the full release would remedy this but it is clearly an issue they have given no thought to at all.

I just wish I had not spent £35 quid and put so much time into this already because as it stands I will now wait until Xmas before I play the game again in vain hope that they update the match engine and game play in a further patch. 

If you feel they same way then let your voices be heard!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
+ The game aims for high realism! Man U, (yes I know I'm not writing it right, but I do it on purpose) is in the bottom and fighting for survival in the PL with over 1billion spent every transferwindow. Arsenal are in the middle of the table, Everton is relegated, Leeds coming out of the Championship, Barcelona vacuuming the best players from Liverpool ... I don't know what could have been more realistic with the game.
+ New features work optimally and are easy to understand.

- If you play a match and have 40 shots, 28 on goal and no one is in, you will be incredibly frustrated.
- That Liverpool do not sell any players in a transitional window, but can still buy Dybala, De Vrij, Ziyech and Van De Beek, is bullshit. so incredibly unlikely transfer windows! 

I have played fm from 2009, before that I have played CM from 2001 (?).
I have now spent almost 40 hours in the beta, most bugs have been wiped away, the new features that have been added work optimally and I like them very well.
the only thing that I'm still not happy with is;
- realism of the transitional windows
- poor graphics engine during matches
- limited options to customize the manager you create
- That you have to tamper with files on the data to name Juventus, Champions leauge and Premier Leauge
- That logos have to be downloaded in order to be decent, this also applies to the team kits.
- Portrait photo for players, should as of today be mandatory.


Don't buy it on sale, it's worth every penny.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
A tour de force.  This is the epitome of football management games.  I would say the match engine still needs a little more work: for example there are too many long shots going in right now.  And I think "gegenpressing" is too effective even with low quality teams.

On the other hand I really like the "inductions".  I haven't played this since 2013 so it was nice to have some introduction to the game's new features.
Overall, its brilliant, and Im already addicted.
9/10.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've played the beta and found that it was very good quality. I had an exciting title race in which I won the league with Liverpool on the final day. There was the occasional glitch: Some highlights were cut in half and others didn't play at all or the  big blue notification at the top of the screen stayed for much longer than necessary. But, these were all small problems. The game ran smoothly. The only proper criticism that the game may have is that my title race was between Liverpool (Me), Man city and ARSENAL (The team that is underperforming in real life) but with dynamic potential and the game being different each save that is acceptable. 
Very good beta 9/10

title: Football Manager 2020
review: So far so good, I only have about 4.5hrs in the Beta, but I've been enjoying what I've seen so far.  I like how the Beginning is easier to understand, especially if you're a newbie.  They take a lot of time in explaining the new features for us veterans and does a good job of refreshing your memory if you haven't played since FM16.  Things have changed a lot since then I would say and all for the Better.  If you have FM19 i'd maybe wait until next years version, but if you're like me and only have FM18 then I would say that FM20 is a definite upgrade and a definite buy.  However, keep in mind I haven't played a match yet this is all purely base on my experience before the 1st match in the pre-season.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: Let me start by saying I own FM 11, 12, 13, 14, 16, 17, 18, and 20 and have 2,517 hours played across all of those versions. This could easily be a thumbs up because I love the FM series as a whole...but DAMN this is literally the same exact game from when I started playing (FM11). Unfortunately this series has fallen into the same yearly update cycle that FIFA has -- making slight modifications/tweaks to the engine + updated roster and selling it as a whole new game at full price. At the end of the day, though, it's still FM and it's still super addicting which has me coming back year after year.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Laaaaadies and gentlemen, welcome to the greatest game there ever was!  Spacebar Smashing Press Conference Simulator!  Once again you can feel the joy of blisters forming on your fingers as you smash that space bar to prompt the game forward as it constantly stops for no real reason multiple times per in game day!  And take your joy to a whole new level in the press conferences as we bring you THE EXACT SAME questions from years gone by, but with the bonus of new questions that make no sense!  Experience the joy of answering the same questions each and every in game week in multiple weekly press conferences.  And don't worry, you still have to do them because your assistant manager will just upset your players if you leave it to him!  Speaking of upset players, they're still here, still moaning, still wanting new contracts in the first year of new contracts and still getting upset about anything and everything just because!  And speaking of inept staff, your chief scout wont even assign someone to watch the next opposition even if he's highly rated and experienced!

I've put a lot of time in to this year and last year.  The core is somewhere buried amongst all the utter tosh the devs throw in every year, but it's getting harder and harder to enjoy.  SI Games seems to have forgotten that people play games to escape the tedium of life and work, not to experience someone else's.  Having multiple press conferences every week with the same quesitons over and over and over and over and over and over is utterly soul destroying, having players whinge constantly is just annoying and does anyone know the point of the judging skills with scouts because the highly skilled and low skilled seem to rate guys the same.

I'll play this, I'll enjoy team building, tactics, transfers and developing young players, but all of that will be severely tarnished by all the add on crap that doesn't need to be there.  And the worst of it is, with the press conferences, this wouldn't be so bad if it was just 2-3 questions once a week.  I wish someone at SI would ask "does it make it more fun" once in a while.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Although there are many new features aimed to improve your gaming experience, match simulation, the core feature of this game is still broken:

1. Home advantage is ridiculous, when you are playing as the away team, you can never score even if you have more than 15 shots and over half of them are on target. On the other hand, the home team scored as soon as they have 1 or 2 shots on target.

2. Players are still doing insane and unreasonable actions, e.g. clearing the ball to my own end line when they got the ball near mid-field. This issue persisted for at least 5 years in this franchise.

3. Players always use header to knock the ball to opponent players even if there is absolutely no threat around him.

4. You can hardly score from 1 on 1 chances, this is very unrealistic, and persisted many years as well.

I recommend against buying Football Manager 2020 at least at this stage unless match simulation has significant improvements.

title: Football Manager 2020
review: Good updates to accurately depict the game in match engine. Slick interface and upgrade from 2019. FYI if you dont want to handle all the club responsibilities, find high quality gm,head of youth dev, chief scouts,coaches, a great asssitant coach (with high man managment and discipline to run general trainings) and let them do all the  nitty gritty so you can focus on your match squad. Currently i know its in beta so i expect spelling correction. Would love to see the 2d engine again, from fm 2017, i dont me 2d classic, but the 2d that looked nice and polished. Still looking for color contrast options in d 3d engine, the colors look so washed in it s original settings. Loving it, its an upgrade from my last buy fm 2017.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Football manager 2020 beta version is terrible, I wait official release.

Firstly, your strikers will miss 1 on 1 chances 9 out of 10 seriously, and the opposition strikers as well. So even if your team adopts an attacking football, you won't get scored a lot, and meanwhile, your strikers shoot 10 and score 1.

I am now playing Arsenal, this team has two good strikers. Lacazette and Aubameyang. 
Now I am leading PL, and they both don't even score 10 goals in the league ( 28  matches passed)
Most of goals came from Xhaka, Guendouzi, David Luiz. Yeah Nicolas Pepe is a good player and he can score. But what about two strikers? They miss 1 on 1 challenge 90%, this is why Auba scores only 8 goals and Lacazette 4. They just boot them to the opposition keeper or goes to over the bar.

But here is the point, I adopt long range shooting tactics, therefore, in away match, I won over Tottenham ( 5-1), Man city ( 2-1) Liverpool ( 4-1 )
so at this time, all you need is adopting a long range tactics and never expect 1 on 1 challenges as your strikers won't score. Meanwhile, any kind of long range shootings from any players will be  scored all the time

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The game engine seems far from finished. Football matches seem rather unrealistic if you just look at the teams moving the ball around.

* Players tend to play the ball back to the goalkeeper, even if they are situated on the opposing half.
* Players tend to cross the ball from the side into their own box (even had an opposing player heading the ball into my goal).
* Long balls are played much too often and cover very long distances, resulting in a lot of 1vs1 situations in front of the goal (in which the player on the ball never scores).
* There are an absurd amount of attacks that turn out to be offside.

I would have rather looked at a functioning 2D pitch than this 3D pitch with 'improved' animations. It really doesn't feel like a game of football anymore...

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Imagine taking your car into a garage for a full service and MOT and all they did was swap your tires around and stick a new smelly dangly thing on your rearview mirror. That's the Football Manager franchise.

Again, this is another 'evolutionary' update with even less in it than usual. You have a data update for the new season, and a few things moved around (player development mostly). The player portraits still look like a police photo-fit of someone they'd like to help them with their enquiries, the match engine is slightly less crap, and the game runs a couple of percent faster with a full database of players.

And that's it... really.

Not worth the release price at all, fair price would be at least half for what is a glorified patch with a data update.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Well, it's a good old (sometimes bad) Football Manager. Not many changes since last year. Still no multi-monitor support, no female football, no possibility to create sandbox leagues, etc (the full list is very long actually). New skin (I fiercely dislike new buttons), updated rosters (and no more Juventus license - have fun eliminating "Zebre" from random game files), some nice, but still minor, improvements. And, of course, REALLY A LOT of woodwork (if you missed couple  FMs, they even hid woodwork from stats).
If you already played FM before, you'll most likely buy it again 'cause there is no competition at all. If not, it's worth trying. With a few clicks, you can control your team better than in scripted simulators like FIFA or PES. There are no major match engine issues this year so the beta is quite playable. Therefore, I recommend it without a doubt and without waiting for a release.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
The Good - 
Much better Game Engine

More interesting Dialogue options and some added media stuff.

Adding seasonal goals has increased the depth and functionality of transfers and signing staff. Players also seem to value these items more than in the past.

Same game fundamentally that I know and love.

The Bad -
I've seen 99.9% of all one on ones go out of bounds or miss. Mine and NPC combined. 50+ Hours played. literally have seen 100s of 1on1 breakaways.

My players also seem to ignore "Shoot Less" and "Work Ball Into Box" and shoot from 30-40 yards out with both instructions.

For some reason the dialogue options are confused. I'm in first playing second place - Dialogue option "The standings currently have us in 4th and our opponents in 1st..."

Also not sure how I am expected to finish in the bottom half of the league. I'm undefeated as of January in the Serie C/C in 1st place with a 6 point lead. If I lost literally every game I have left I'd still finish comfortably in 12th. This affects everything from dialogue options, future player signings and betting odds. This is an ongoing problem that needs to be fixed.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've owned every Football Manager for nearly a decade. I skipped FM 19 here on Steam but bought FM 19 Touch on the Nintendo Switch.

FM 2020 is more of the same with some solid improvements. Certainly compared to 18, the quick tactic creator can be great for newer players who don't quite know what every tactic option does. Pick a template (with helpful in-game descriptions on what exactly the tactics do), tweak it a bit for how your team plays, and you're good to go. The more detail training schedules help out too to really focus your team's weaknessses, rather than forcing you into broad attacking/defense/technical categories.

I really think FM 20 is the best starter entry into the series in a long time. Doesn't mean you're guaranteed success or a championship, especially if you start on a top-league team with no experience. But it walks you through the basics of setting up your team even if you don't bother delegating tasks to your coaching staff, and even if you lose, you'll at least have some idea WHY you're losing.

Overall an excellent addition to the franchise.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
TL:DR - Solid release with lots of small and large improvements, however some of the same issues still present.

For me this is probably the strongest release in a long time so far. Engine feels slightly improved from last year with only a couple of bugs noticed and some of the common ones from the previous releases fixed.

PROS

As well as that they have once again added a new large feature in the player development system, I am yet to get stuck into it however it looks a decent addition with some nice tools for developing your youth teams. They have definitely expanded in this area.

As well as the major additions they have refined and sharpened a lot of existing content and features. I really enjoy the expanded staff responsibilities. Allows you to make a lot more use out of your backroom team, I have hired a really strong Head of Youth development in my game and given him permission to find and sign new players for the U18s, however I have kept responsibility for the final say meaning if the players not good enough or in a position thats already saturated I can veto it.

There are very minor improvements that only experienced players will likely even notice and even I am finding hard to recall. One example I can say is that when you get promoted from lower leagues in previous game you always go into the next season 500-1 or even 1000-1 to win the league, regardless of signings or how good your team is.

This is the first time where the odds actually reflected reality when I went up. My players were really strong and I made big loan signings. We started the season at 16-1 to go up. It felt more realistic.

Another example of these minor improvements and refinements was when negotiating deals. In previous titles I found the player demands pre contract were virtually useless. You could just remove them all and the player would still be happy to negotiate, he might just ask for a little more money.

Not any more, players will reject negotiations more often if you remove all there demands.

There are lots of tweaks and changes like this and they add up to a more immersive and enjoyable game with more problems to solve and elements to manage and balance. May add more of the better ones when I encounter them in my game and am reminded.

The overall UI is an improvement for me also, feels clearer and more concise. Easier to navigate.

CONS

Some of the small main issues and in my opinion the one big problem with FM still exist.

Small issues like team shouts being too repetitive and not really dynamic, unrealistic player fallout when a shitty 4th choice defender is unhappy he isn't starting, teams worse then yours offering you a job every week when your doing well etc. A lot of these still haven't been addressed, though some of them have as I pointed to in my previous section. These didn't make the game unplayable then and don't know.

The main issue is still there for me. Once you have mastered the game its too easy and always will be. For experienced players who understand the games tactical and man management systems it becomes far too easy. I am able to take a conference team to the premiership in 5-7 seasons every single game I start without fail. The tactics I play haven't changed since FM2016 really, they were tweaked in the last tactical overhaul but the principle is still the same.

I just follow the same tried and tested formula. Its always the same and there isn't really that big a challenge anymore.

The game is still fun for me and I enjoy growing my team, discovering new talent, taking my team from the lowest league to the best team in the world and doing big money negotiations etc.

But as well as new features and expansions on what is there I long for a new challenge in the games existing mechanics. Maybe a harder mode with some new problems to deal with, or where the existing problems are tougher to deal with or identify. 

The last few releases have added a lot of identification and prevention tools, I think this was largely down to the community complaining about the game being broken in regards to the match engine, injuries and tactics etc.

SI do listen to the fan base and gave a lot of ways to make identification of these complaints easier, as virtually 99% of the time it was the player not managing properly, not an issue with the game.

I fear SI will never be able to please everyone in this regard and they have settled on a balance between the two types of players.

What we have here is the best football management game there has ever been or will be, every year improvements are made and this year is no different. This may even be the greatest Tycoon / simulation game ever made. 10/10 everytime.

(12hrs in) Just getting started but it already proving to be an awesome game.
I did not play much of FM18 and FM19 but I played the hell out of FM17. So far FM20 is a great improvement, although I find the 3D match graphics to be a bit dull (especially the pitches) and the animation is almost worse than FM17.
The game also runs much faster and smoothly than FM18 and FM19 in every way. This is a big plus for me as I play on an old i5 laptop with an Intel graphics card.
Great game overall.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
I've been playing Football Manager since it used to be called Championship Manager in the season of 96/97.

Even then it was more balanced than it is now.

I have to say this is the most unbalanced and unrealistic FM I have ever played.

3 Seasons in and every single season the same happens. I play with FC Porto, and it's impossible to win the league. SL Benfica always wins it even though I completely destroy them in every match we face each other.

My results with them are always 3-0, 4-0 and even 5-0. But what happens is that SL Benfica doesn't lose any points other than the points they lose against me, meaning they always win every single match and finish top of the league with an unrealistic 90+ points.

Other than this, in 3 seasons clubs such as Chelsea and Manchester City have become bankrupt?!?

Edited: Finished second place in the league one point from first place. At the end of the third season, the day after I won the Portuguese Cup and the last match of the season (second cup won that season) I got told off by the board for failing to win the Cup I had just won (I know right?!?). Got sacked a few days later!

Well done, this is the worst FM yet...

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
As of this title I've played every Football Manager game since 2012 on Steam.

While I'll recommend this game, from what I've seen so far it's a small visual update to the previous years game with a greater emphasis to changes to the in game systems and mechanics surrounding the management of your club. 

I've come across some errors with the in game 3D engine not always matching up with the calls being made (i.e. constant offside calls when in the 3D match engine its clearly onside) but that is probably a beta issue. The 3D engine doesn't appear to be greatly improved graphically, but I've noticed more nuanced movement and animations with the players on the pitch. 

Player management, particularly squad management has changed somewhat and there are even more ways to classify your players and set training now.

You may view this as being more of the same but in my experience that's not always a bad thing with Football Manager.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Great improvements already in the beta version - the new features add more depth and allow for players to focus on micromanaging or delegating.
In any case, there are a lot of issues to iron out still.
- One on ones (as mentioned in a lot of other reviews) are missed at an extraordinary rate.
- The fact that there are *so many* one on ones every game also needs review, since it's unrealistic.
- Defensive line mechanics don't seem to be working properly, they always allow for strikers to dash behind defenders.
- When facing the goal, strikers (or any other player for that matter) always goes for goal and never passes to a better placed teammate, even if the other player is all alone in front of goal and the striker doesn't have a clear angle.
- Selecting low or whipped crosses doesn't really change anything.
- A few of the club vision criteria are not measured properly. For example, if the club doesn't expect you to sign players over 30, and you sign 8 players of 20 or under, they will still be "reserving judgment" even after two years managing the team.
- Transfer negotiation between clubs (or contracts with players / agents) need a bit of rework. Negotiations are easily broken for minor reasons.
- Conversations with players who are unhappy (want a new contract, etc) should also be reviewed. They sometimes request an improved contract "just because", and the conversation itself doesn't always go OK even if you promise to offer a new one.

Regardless of the issues stated above, I still strongly recommend it. I trust the issues will be sorted, the game stabilised, and all in all it's a great game.
(remember this is still a beta version)

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Same old problems in this one. Reminds me of the 2018 version. You can´t score a goal if your life depended on it. You get 3-4 shots to woodwork in most games. You can get 15-20 shots on goal and you just can´t score. Even on penalties the goalkeepers win 75-25. I haven´t seen a striker score from a breakaway and it is now january in english premier league. Not mine or from the opposition. The keeper takes it or they shoot behind the goal.
Nothing in the game tactis you can do to make people score. And I am able to create premium scoring chances...

For example, I played with Everton against Newcastle. 
Shots 47-2
Shots on goal 20-1
Possession 69-31
I hit the goalposts 5 times.
Newcastle had a red card in the end.

Result: 0-0.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
This is the first time I have pre-ordered a Football Manager game, and it didn't disappoint. I'll happily admit that I haven't bought a Football Manager game since 2017, due to feeling like nothing was ever really changing. But this time seemed different, and how right I was to make the early investment this time around.

As a Football Coach in real life, it's great to see more control over the development of youth players and how the backroom staff can help make or break a player, depending on their own skills as a coach. Before I would pick a lower league side and try to work my way up...it didn't matter what the skill of my players were, we could get promoted every season. But now it feels more realistic, which I love. Destined for relegation? Then you probably will without a decent training set up and well thought through tactics.

Choices matter now. Early pre-season is actually important and can effect how your team manages the start of the season...player negotiations are much more realistic too! (Though the constant emails from the scouting meeting can get annoying, when you're not looking to expand).

Overall, worth the wait and highly reccommend as the best football management game out there!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
As an FM player since 2011 I can safely say that this game is a definite improvement upon FM19.

As a lot of reviewers have also mentioned; the match engine has come leaps and bounds from last years game. FM19's match engine was annoyingly repetitive despite changing tactics, players made the same decisions, stayed in the same position and made odd mistakes that shouldn't be made. So yeah a huge plus point.

I actually really like the new youth development tab. As a player that likes to frequently bring through youth players, this makes this style of management so much easier. Whilst earlier games weren't very thorough in keeping track of players out on loan, a quick click can view this.

Don't expect any UI changes or match graphics to be improved as these are spitting images of last years games. I don't think the UI is bad, but previous versions were definitely better. Most FM veterans will agree.

Delegation of staff responsibilities has been tweaked for the better. I personally prefer my coaches to set opposition instructions and now they'll make these changes for you throughout each match, a big plus point.

Although this game is far to similar to FM19, the tweaks and changes that have been made are worth investing into.

8/10

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Note: It's been a couple years since I seriously played an FM release. I can't comment as a frequent player on the year-to-year transition, but as someone coming back, I can resoundingly say this has been great coming back after I skipped a couple. 

Let's be honest... we know why we're here. Only the hardiest of souls dare wander into sports management sims, but you're here, and you're ready.

For me, having some of the old features feel like an old pair of boots is incredibly welcome. I wandered right back into core mechanics that were familiar, and that was great. Tactics, signing players, match play, etc. 

Some of the new features are really great and will be underrated/underappreciated at first. Club Vision is very relatable to real world scenarios, and I did new (to me) backroom staff roles.

Also, I do not believe it's new, but I absolutely love the Social Group and Team Hierarchy mechanics! Having both personal and team personalities is slick, and recognizable players on a team coalesce or conflict with each other can either bring teams together or rip them apart. 

Match play seems super solid, and I appreciate that shouts work! I've started with Crewe Alexandra, primarily because as an American traveling through London and Manchester, I always transfer in Crewe (and my real world experience with Arsenal is already traumatic enough).

I haven't messed with training, but that's the next goal. ;)

All in all, I am simply having fun with FM2020. For someone that travels quite a bit, it'll be the go-to travel game on my laptop for a long time.

review: Honestly the beta match engine is quite bad right now (almost impossible to score one v ones, wingers shooting from impossible angles instead of passing into the box, way too many shots, unrealistic long balls, too many long range goals and so on) but it is only the beta. Hopefully it'll get an update on release because it has the potential to be a fantastic edition to the series.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Didn't play a FM since FM16 and i have to say, the game has improved A LOT since then.

- match engine is better
- it moves fluidly
- good response time and pretty much no waiting time between days
- UI is clear
- team talk seems to actually make an impact
- no crazy out of the blue gazillion injuries

I like to start in the lowest league in Italy or England and work my way up to win Champions League and so far i'm having a blast.

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
7/10 - Not too dissimilar from FM19. Few changes here and there however for me personally not too many 'drastic, game changing' feature. i'm and advocate of the development centre feature as i feel it's a huge part of the bringing through to the senior squad. 

Again not many changes in the actual gameplay part of the game, a few new motions for GK saves and headers from what i've seen but also the unrealistic crossing with back to the goal and a few stupid looking shots still. 

With only 5 hours into the game and roughly 3 games into the season in my first save I'd say it's an upgrade but let's face it, for the avid FM gamer we're always going to buy it!

title: Football Manager 2020
review:
Great BETA, loved it. But there are some small stuff to be fixed as usual.

*BETA Flaws*

- Players are not getting linked (e.g. green line when wing back and winger getting used to play with each other.)

- Goalkeeper stats graphic are too bright their stat graphics are almost invisible.

- 3D matches are laggy (i need to change settings to lowest before match then back to higher during match to fix the lag)

- Dark skin is not actually dark on some inbox messages.

- When using searching on drop tab menu, pressing on keyboard buttons to fast access not working. (e.g. clicking E to select England easier, not working)

- When saving team selections, box that we are writing down the selection name is not activated until clicking on box or pressing tab button on keyboard. On FM19 it was automatically activated.

- Sweeper Keepers are tend to not distribute to defenders, instead they like to kick the ball to further teammates.
